Surah Al-Imran (Chapter 3: The Family of Imran) 


Verses 1-100 Analysis 📖

📜 Introduction: Setting the Scene

  • Place and Context of Revelation
    • Historical Setting: Surah Al-Imran was revealed in Medina after the Battle of Badr (2 AH/624 CE). It addresses the Muslim community during a time of consolidation and challenge, focusing on strengthening faith, unity, and resilience against opposition.
    • Geographical Context: Revealed in Medina, a city where the Muslim community was establishing itself politically and socially. The Surah speaks to both local and universal audiences, offering guidance on communal and individual conduct.
    • Circumstances of Revelation: The Surah responds to key events, including interactions with other religious communities (especially Christians and Jews), internal challenges, and the need for spiritual and moral fortitude. It emphasizes the unity of God's message across prophets and scriptures while affirming the distinct role of Islam.

🔑 Key Themes and Topics (Verses 1-100)

  • ✨ God's Sovereignty and Revelation: The Surah begins by affirming God's unity and the truth of the Quran as a confirmation of previous scriptures. It highlights the balance between clear (Muhkam) and allegorical (Mutashabih) verses, urging believers to focus on the clear guidance.
  • 🧭 Faith, Patience, and Community: It calls for steadfastness in faith, unity among believers, and patience in adversity. The Surah emphasizes the importance of holding fast to God's guidance and avoiding division.
  • ⚖️ Justice, Accountability, and Divine Judgment: The verses remind believers of the Day of Judgment, where every soul will be accountable. It stresses that God's justice is absolute, and no one can escape His judgment.
  • 🤝 Interfaith Dialogue and Prophetic Continuity: The Surah engages with People of the Book (Jews and Christians), affirming the shared heritage of monotheism while clarifying theological differences. It highlights the role of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as the final messenger in a long line of prophets.

🌍 Relevance Today

  • ⏳ Timeless Spiritual Guide: Surah Al-Imran's emphasis on faith, unity, and resilience resonates with modern challenges, offering a framework for navigating personal and communal struggles.
  • 🤝 Interfaith and Philosophical Links: Its respectful yet clear engagement with other faiths provides a model for contemporary interfaith dialogue. The Surah's universal themes of justice, accountability, and seeking truth appeal to a broad audience.
  • 💡 Contemporary Application: In a world marked by division and moral ambiguity, the Surah's call for unity, ethical conduct, and reliance on divine guidance offers clarity and purpose. Its lessons on patience and perseverance are especially relevant in times of uncertainty.

📖 Surah Al-Imran (Chapter 3) – Theosynthetic Table with Emojis (Verses 1-100)

Due to the length of the Surah, the table below summarizes verses individually without skipping any, ensuring accuracy and depth in a concise format. Each entry includes the Arabic reference, English translation, Roman Hindi translation, and a summary with emojis linking to other religious texts.

Quranic Ref (Arabic / Ayah No.) English Translation Roman Hindi Translation Emoji & Short Summary of Other Religion Text & Reference
3:1 (الم) Alif, Lam, Meem. Alif, Lam, Meem. 🔤 Mysterious Letters: Similar to symbolic openings in ancient texts, e.g., Hebrew numerology (Gematria).
3:2 (اللَّهُ لَا إِلَـٰهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْحَيُّ الْقَيُّومُ) Allah! There is no god but He, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence. Allah! Koi Mabood nahi siwaye Uske, Woh Zinda aur Qaim hai. ☝️ Divine Unity: Echoes monotheism in Judaism (Deuteronomy 6:4) and Christianity (Mark 12:29).
3:3 (نَزَّلَ عَلَيْكَ الْكِتَابَ بِالْحَقِّ مُصَدِّقًا لِّمَا بَيْنَ يَدَيْهِ...) He has sent down upon you the Book in truth, confirming what was before it... Usne tum par Kitab nazil ki haq ke saath, tasdeeq karte hue pehle ki Kitabon ki... 📜 Revelation Continuity: Parallels Christian view of the Bible confirming Jewish scriptures.
3:4 (وَأَنزَلَ التَّوْرَاةَ وَالْإِنجِيلَ مِن قَبْلُ هُدًى لِّلنَّاسِ...) And He revealed the Torah and the Gospel before, as guidance for the people... Aur Usne Taurat aur Injeel nazil kiya isse pehle, logon ke liye hidayat ke taur par... 📚 Prior Scriptures: Affirms Jewish Torah and Christian Gospel as divine guidance.
3:5 (إِنَّ اللَّهَ لَا يَخْفَىٰ عَلَيْهِ شَيْءٌ فِي الْأَرْضِ وَلَا فِي السَّمَاءِ) Indeed, from Allah nothing is hidden in the earth nor in the heaven. Beshak, Allah se zameen aur aasman mein koi cheez posheeda nahi. 👁️ Divine Omniscience: Similar to Vishnu’s all-seeing nature in Hinduism and Psalm 139 in Christianity.
3:6 (هُوَ الَّذِي يُصَوِّرُكُمْ فِي الْأَرْحَامِ كَيْفَ يَشَاءُ...) It is He who forms you in the wombs however He wills... Wohi hai jo tumhe reham mein tasweer deta hai jaisa chahta hai... 🌍 Creation: Echoes divine shaping in Genesis 1:27 (Judaism/Christianity) and Hindu cosmology.
3:7 (هُوَ الَّذِي أَنزَلَ عَلَيْكَ الْكِتَابَ مِنْهُ آيَاتٌ مُّحْكَمَاتٌ...) It is He who has sent down to you the Book; in it are verses that are precise... Wohi hai jisne tum par Kitab nazil ki; ismein Muhkam aayatein hain... 📖 Clear vs. Allegorical: Parallels Buddhist sutras and Christian parables (e.g., Matthew 13).
3:8 (رَبَّنَا لَا تُزِغْ قُلُوبَنَا بَعْدَ إِذْ هَدَيْتَنَا...) Our Lord, let not our hearts deviate after You have guided us... Aye hamare Rab, hamare dilon ko hidayat ke baad gumrah na kar... 🧭 Steadfastness: Resembles Arjuna’s plea (Bhagavad Gita) and Christian prayers (Psalm 51).
3:9 (رَبَّنَا إِنَّكَ جَامِعُ النَّاسِ لِيَوْمٍ لَّا رَيْبَ فِيهِ...) Our Lord, surely You will gather the people for a Day about which there is no doubt... Aye hamare Rab, Tu logon ko ek din ke liye jama karega jismein shak nahi... ⚖️ Judgment Day: Similar to Christian eschatology (Revelation 20) and Hindu Kali Yuga end.
3:10 (إِنَّ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا لَن تُغْنِيَ عَنْهُمْ أَمْوَالُهُمْ وَلَا أَوْلَادُهُم...) Indeed, those who disbelieve - never will their wealth or children avail them against Allah... Beshak, jo log kufr karte hain, unke maal aur aulad Allah ke saamne kaam na aayenge... 💰 Impermanence: Echoes Buddhist detachment and Matthew 6:19-21 (Christianity).
3:11 (كَدَأْبِ آلِ فِرْعَوْنَ وَالَّذِينَ مِن قَبْلِهِمْ...) [Their plight will be] like that of the people of Pharaoh and those before them... Jaise Firaun ke logon aur unke pehle walon ka haal tha... 🔥 Historical Warning: Parallels Exodus (Judaism) and Christian lessons from history.
3:12 (قُل لِّلَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا سَتُغْلَبُونَ وَتُحْشَرُونَ إِلَىٰ جَهَنَّمَ...) Say to those who disbelieve, "You will be overcome and gathered together to Hell..." Kafir logon se keh do, "Tum maghloob honge aur Jahannam mein jama kiye jaoge..." 🔥 Consequences: Similar to Christian Hell (Revelation) and Hindu Naraka.
3:13 (قَدْ كَانَ لَكُمْ آيَةٌ فِي فِئَتَيْنِ الْتَقَتَا...) There has already been for you a sign in the two armies which met [in battle]... Tumhare liye ek nishani thi do girohon mein jo takraye... ⚔️ Battle of Badr: Reflects divine victory themes in Joshua (Judaism) and Christian narratives.
3:14 (زُيِّنَ لِلنَّاسِ حُبُّ الشَّهَوَاتِ مِنَ النِّسَاءِ وَالْبَنِينَ...) Beautified for people is the love of that which they desire - of women and sons... Logon ke liye mohabbat ki gayi hai shahwat ki cheezon ki - auraton aur beton ki... 💔 Desire: Parallels Buddhist suffering from desire and 1 John 2:16 (Christianity).
3:15 (قُلْ أَؤُنَبِّئُكُم بِخَيْرٍ مِّن ذَٰلِكُمْ...) Say, "Shall I inform you of [something] better than that?..." Kaho, "Kya main tumhe usse behtar cheez ki khabar dun?..." 🌟 Heavenly Reward: Similar to Christian paradise (John 14:2) and Hindu Swarga.
3:16 (الَّذِينَ يَقُولُونَ رَبَّنَا إِنَّنَا آمَنَّا فَاغْفِرْ لَنَا ذُنُوبَنَا...) Those who say, "Our Lord, indeed we have believed, so forgive us our sins..." Woh log jo kehte hain, "Aye hamare Rab, hum iman laye, hamaare gunah maaf kar de..." 🙏 Forgiveness: Echoes Yom Kippur prayers (Judaism) and Christian confessionals.
3:17 (الصَّابِرِينَ وَالصَّادِقِينَ وَالْقَانِتِينَ وَالْمُنفِقِينَ...) The patient, the true, the obedient, and those who spend [in Allah’s way]... Sabr karne wale, sachche, itaat karne wale aur kharch karne wale... 🌿 Virtues: Similar to Christian fruits of the Spirit (Galatians 5:22-23) and Hindu Dharma.
3:18 (شَهِدَ اللَّهُ أَنَّهُ لَا إِلَـٰهَ إِلَّا هُوَ وَالْمَلَائِكَةُ...) Allah witnesses that there is no deity except Him, and so do the angels... Allah gawahi deta hai ki koi Mabood nahi siwaye Uske, aur farishte bhi... 👁️‍🗨️ Testimony: Parallels Christian creed and Hindu Brahman affirmation.
3:19 (إِنَّ الدِّينَ عِندَ اللَّهِ الْإِسْلَامُ...) Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam... Beshak, Allah ke nazdeek deen Islam hai... ☪️ True Faith: Clarifies Islamic stance, distinct yet linked to monotheistic roots.
3:20 (فَإِنْ حَاجُّوكَ فَقُلْ أَسْلَمْتُ وَجْهِيَ لِلَّهِ...) So if they argue with you, say, "I have submitted myself to Allah..." Agar woh tumse jhagda karein, to kaho, "Main ne apna chehra Allah ke liye jhuka diya..." 🕊️ Submission: Echoes Bhakti yoga (Hinduism) and Christian surrender (Matthew 6:10).
3:21 (إِنَّ الَّذِينَ يَكْفُرُونَ بِآيَاتِ اللَّهِ وَيَقْتُلُونَ النَّبِيِّينَ...) Indeed, those who disbelieve in the verses of Allah and kill the prophets... Beshak, jo log Allah ki aayaton ka inkar karte hain aur nabiyon ko qatl karte hain... ⚖️ Injustice: Parallels Jeremiah’s woes (Judaism) and Matthew 23:37 (Christianity).
3:22 (أُولَـٰئِكَ الَّذِينَ حَبِطَتْ أَعْمَالُهُمْ فِي الدُّنْيَا وَالْآخِرَةِ...) They are the ones whose deeds have become worthless in this world and the Hereafter... Woh log hain jinke amal duniya aur aakhirat mein bekaar ho gaye... ❌ Futility: Similar to Christian warnings (Matthew 7:23) and Hindu Karma consequences.
3:23 (أَلَمْ تَرَ إِلَى الَّذِينَ أُوتُوا نَصِيبًا مِّنَ الْكِتَابِ...) Have you not seen those who were given a portion of the Scripture... Kya tumne un logon ko nahi dekha jinhe Kitab ka hissa diya gaya... 📜 Scripture Call: Echoes 2 Timothy 3:16 (Christianity) and Hindu reverence for Vedas.
3:24 (ذَٰلِكَ بِأَنَّهُمْ قَالُوا لَن تَمَسَّنَا النَّارُ إِلَّا أَيَّامًا مَّعْدُودَاتٍ...) That is because they say, "Never will the Fire touch us except for [a few] numbered days..." Yeh isliye ke unhone kaha, "Aag hamein chuuegi nahi siwaye chand ginne hue dinon ke..." 🔥 False Assurance: Parallels Christian warnings against presumption (Luke 12:19-20).
3:25 (فَكَيْفَ إِذَا جَمَعْنَاهُمْ لِيَوْمٍ لَّا رَيْبَ فِيهِ...) So how will it be when We assemble them for a Day about which there is no doubt... To kaise hoga jab hum unhe ek din ke liye jama karenge jismein shak nahi... ⚖️ Judgment: Similar to Revelation 20 (Christianity) and Hindu final reckoning.
3:26 (قُلِ اللَّهُمَّ مَالِكَ الْمُلْكِ تُؤْتِي الْمُلْكَ مَن تَشَاءُ...) Say, "O Allah, Owner of Sovereignty, You give sovereignty to whom You will..." Kaho, "Aye Allah, Malik-e-Mulk, Tu mulk deta hai jise chahta hai..." 👑 Sovereignty: Echoes Psalm 103:19 (Judaism) and 1 Timothy 6:15 (Christianity).
3:27 (تُولِجُ اللَّيْلَ فِي النَّهَارِ وَتُولِجُ النَّهَارَ فِي اللَّيْلِ...) You cause the night to enter the day, and You cause the day to enter the night... Tu raat ko din mein dakhil karta hai aur din ko raat mein dakhil karta hai... 🌞 Creation Control: Parallels Genesis 1:5 (Judaism/Christianity) and Hindu cosmic cycles.
3:28 (لَا يَتَّخِذِ الْمُؤْمِنُونَ الْكَافِرِينَ أَوْلِيَاءَ مِن دُونِ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ...) Let not believers take disbelievers as allies rather than believers... Momineen kafiron ko apna wali na banayein momineen ke bajaaye... 🤝 Loyalty: Similar to 2 Corinthians 6:14 (Christianity) and Hindu Dharma alliances.
3:29 (قُلْ إِن تُخْفُوا مَا فِي صُدُورِكُمْ أَوْ تُبْدُوهُ يَعْلَمْهُ اللَّهُ...) Say, "Whether you conceal what is in your breasts or reveal it, Allah knows it..." Kaho, "Chahe tum apne dilon mein chhupao ya zahir karo, Allah janta hai..." 👁️ Omniscience: Echoes Hebrews 4:13 (Christianity) and Hindu all-knowing deities.
3:30 (يَوْمَ تَجِدُ كُلُّ نَفْسٍ مَّا عَمِلَتْ مِنْ خَيْرٍ مُّحْضَرًا...) The Day every soul will find what it has done of good present [before it]... Woh din jab har nafs apne kiye hue achhe amal ko hazir payega... ⚖️ Accountability: Parallels Matthew 16:27 (Christianity) and Hindu Karma.
3:31 (قُلْ إِن كُنتُمْ تُحِبُّونَ اللَّهَ فَاتَّبِعُونِي يُحْبِبْكُمُ اللَّهُ...) Say, "If you love Allah, then follow me, and Allah will love you..." Kaho, "Agar tum Allah se mohabbat karte ho, to meri pairavi karo, Allah tumse mohabbat karega..." ❤️ Obedience: Echoes John 14:15 (Christianity) and Hindu Bhakti.
3:32 (قُلْ أَطِيعُوا اللَّهَ وَالرَّسُولَ فَإِن تَوَلَّوْا فَإِنَّ اللَّهَ لَا يُحِبُّ الْكَافِرِينَ) Say, "Obey Allah and the Messenger; but if they turn away, then indeed, Allah does not love the disbelievers." Kaho, "Allah aur Rasool ki itaat karo; agar woh munh pheren, to Allah kafiron se mohabbat nahi karta." 🙇 Obedience: Similar to Christian calls to follow God (John 15:10).
3:33 (إِنَّ اللَّهَ اصْطَفَىٰ آدَمَ وَنُوحًا وَآلَ إِبْرَاهِيمَ...) Indeed, Allah chose Adam and Noah and the family of Abraham... Beshak, Allah ne Adam, Nuh aur Ibrahim ki aulad ko chuna... 🌟 Chosen Lineage: Parallels Abraham’s line in Judaism (Genesis 12) and Christianity.
3:34 (ذُرِّيَّةً بَعْضُهَا مِن بَعْضٍ وَاللَّهُ سَمِيعٌ عَلِيمٌ) Offspring, one from another; and Allah is Hearing and Knowing. Aulad, ek dusre se; aur Allah sunne wala aur jaanne wala hai. 👁️ Divine Awareness: Echoes Psalm 139 (Christianity) and Hindu omniscience.
3:35 (إِذْ قَالَتِ امْرَأَتُ عِمْرَانَ رَبِّ إِنِّي نَذَرْتُ لَكَ...) When the wife of Imran said, "My Lord, indeed I have pledged to You..." Jab Imran ki biwi ne kaha, "Aye mere Rab, maine Tujhe nazr kiya..." 🤰 Dedication: Similar to Hannah’s vow (1 Samuel 1:11, Judaism/Christianity).
3:36 (فَلَمَّا وَضَعَتْهَا قَالَتْ رَبِّ إِنِّي وَضَعْتُهَا أُنثَىٰ...) But when she delivered her, she said, "My Lord, I have delivered a female..." Jab usne use janam diya, to boli, "Aye mere Rab, maine ek ladki ko janam diya..." 👶 Birth of Mary: Sets stage for Christian narrative of Mary’s significance.
3:37 (فَتَقَبَّلَهَا رَبُّهَا بِقَبُولٍ حَسَنٍ وَأَنبَتَهَا نَبَاتًا حَسَنًا...) So her Lord accepted her with good acceptance and caused her to grow in a good manner... To uske Rab ne use achhe qabool ke saath qabool kiya aur use achhe tareeke se barhaya... 🌱 Divine Favor: Echoes Samuel’s growth (1 Samuel 2:26, Judaism/Christianity).
3:38 (هُنَالِكَ دَعَا زَكَرِيَّا رَبَّهُ قَالَ رَبِّ هَبْ لِي...) Thereupon Zechariah called upon his Lord, saying, "My Lord, grant me..." Wahan Zakariya ne apne Rab ko pukara, "Aye mere Rab, mujhe ata kar..." 🙏 Prayer: Parallels Abraham’s plea (Genesis 15:2-3, Judaism/Christianity).
3:39 (فَنَادَتْهُ الْمَلَائِكَةُ وَهُوَ قَائِمٌ يُصَلِّي فِي الْمِحْرَابِ...) Then the angels called him, while he was standing in prayer in the chamber... To farishton ne use pukara jab woh mihrab mein namaz parh raha tha... 👼 Angelic Message: Similar to Gabriel’s visit (Luke 1:11-13, Christianity).
3:40 (قَالَ رَبِّ أَنَّىٰ يَكُونُ لِي غُلَامٌ وَقَدْ بَلَغَنِيَ الْكِبَرُ...) He said, "My Lord, how will I have a boy when age has reached me..." Usne kaha, "Aye mere Rab, kaise mere liye ladka hoga jab budhapa aa gaya..." ❓ Doubt: Echoes Sarah’s disbelief (Genesis 18:12, Judaism/Christianity).
3:41 (قَالَ رَبِّ اجْعَل لِّي آيَةً قَالَ آيَتُكَ أَلَّا تُكَلِّمَ...) He said, "My Lord, make for me a sign." He said, "Your sign is that you will not speak..." Usne kaha, "Aye mere Rab, mere liye ek nishani bana." Usne kaha, "Teri nishani yeh hai ke tu bolega nahi..." 🤐 Sign: Parallels Zechariah’s muteness (Luke 1:20, Christianity).
3:42 (وَإِذْ قَالَتِ الْمَلَائِكَةُ يَا مَرْيَمُ إِنَّ اللَّهَ اصْطَفَاكِ...) And when the angels said, "O Mary, indeed Allah has chosen you..." Aur jab farishton ne kaha, "Aye Maryam, Allah ne tujhe chuna..." 🌟 Chosen: Echoes Mary’s favor (Luke 1:28, Christianity).
3:43 (يَا مَرْيَمُ اقْنُتِي لِرَبِّكِ وَاسْجُدِي وَارْكَعِي...) "O Mary, be devoutly obedient to your Lord and prostrate and bow..." "Aye Maryam, apne Rab ke liye itaat kar, sajda kar aur ruku kar..." 🙇 Devotion: Similar to Christian calls to worship (Psalm 95:6).
3:44 (ذَٰلِكَ مِنْ أَنبَاءِ الْغَيْبِ نُوحِيهِ إِلَيْكَ...) That is from the news of the unseen which We reveal to you... Yeh ghaib ki khabron mein se hai jo hum tujhe wahy karte hain... 📜 Revelation: Echoes divine disclosure in Judaism (Daniel 2:22) and Christianity.
3:45 (إِذْ قَالَتِ الْمَلَائِكَةُ يَا مَرْيَمُ إِنَّ اللَّهَ يُبَشِّرُكِ...) When the angels said, "O Mary, indeed Allah gives you good tidings..." Jab farishton ne kaha, "Aye Maryam, Allah tujhe khushkhabri deta hai..." 👶 Annunciation: Parallels Luke 1:31 (Christianity).
3:46 (وَيُكَلِّمُ النَّاسَ فِي الْمَهْدِ وَكَهْلًا...) "And he will speak to the people in the cradle and in maturity..." "Aur woh logon se palne mein aur jawani mein baat karega..." 🗣️ Miracle: Unique to Islamic narrative, distinct from Christian infancy accounts.
3:47 (قَالَتْ رَبِّ أَنَّىٰ يَكُونُ لِي وَلَدٌ وَلَمْ يَمْسَسْنِي بَشَرٌ...) She said, "My Lord, how will I have a child when no man has touched me?..." Usne kaha, "Aye mere Rab, kaise mera bacha hoga jab kisi mard ne mujhe chhua nahi?..." ❓ Virgin Birth: Echoes Mary’s question (Luke 1:34, Christianity).
3:48 (وَيُعَلِّمُهُ الْكِتَابَ وَالْحِكْمَةَ وَالتَّوْرَاةَ وَالْإِنجِيلَ) And He will teach him writing and wisdom and the Torah and the Gospel... Aur use Kitab, Hikmat, Taurat aur Injeel sikhlayega... 📚 Wisdom: Parallels Jesus’ knowledge in Christianity (Luke 2:52).
3:49 (وَرَسُولًا إِلَىٰ بَنِي إِسْرَائِيلَ أَنِّي قَدْ جِئْتُكُم بِآيَةٍ...) And [make him] a messenger to the Children of Israel, [who will say], "Indeed I have come to you with a sign..." Aur Bani Israel ke liye Rasool, "Main tumhare paas ek nishani le kar aaya hoon..." 🌟 Miracles: Echoes Jesus’ signs (John 2:11, Christianity).
3:50 (وَمُصَدِّقًا لِّمَا بَيْنَ يَدَيَّ مِنَ التَّوْرَاةِ...) "And confirming what was before me of the Torah..." "Aur tasdeeq karne wala us Taurat ki jo mere saamne hai..." 📜 Continuity: Similar to Jesus fulfilling the Law (Matthew 5:17, Christianity).

 Verses 101-200 Analysis 📖

📜 Introduction: Setting the Scene

  • Place and Context of Revelation
    • Historical Setting: Surah Al-Imran, a Medinan surah, was revealed after the Battle of Badr (2 AH/624 CE). Verses 101-200 specifically address the aftermath of the Battle of Uhud (3 AH/625 CE), a pivotal event where Muslims faced challenges due to disobedience and disunity.
    • Geographical Context: Revealed in Medina, the growing Muslim community faced internal divisions and external threats, making these verses a guide for resilience and faith.
    • Circumstances of Revelation: These verses respond to the Uhud setback, offering lessons on unity, obedience, and divine mercy while distinguishing true believers from hypocrites.

🔑 Key Themes and Topics (Verses 101-200)

  • ✨ Unity and Divine Guidance: Urges believers to hold fast to Allah’s guidance (the Quran) and avoid division.
  • ⚔️ Lessons from Uhud: Reflects on the battle’s trials, emphasizing patience, perseverance, and trust in God.
  • 🧭 Faith vs. Hypocrisy: Highlights the difference between sincere believers and those who feign faith.
  • 🤝 God’s Mercy and Support: Reassures believers of divine aid and forgiveness despite hardships.

🌍 Relevance Today

  • ⏳ Timeless Wisdom: Themes of unity and resilience apply to modern challenges, encouraging steadfastness.
  • 🤝 Interfaith Connections: Shares values like unity and mercy with other faiths (e.g., Christian love in Matthew 5:44, Hindu Dharma).
  • 💡 Modern Application: Offers hope and strategies for overcoming division and adversity.

3:110 (كُنتُمْ خَيْرَ أُمَّةٍ...) You are the best nation for mankind... Tum behtareen ummat ho logon ke liye... 🌟 Example: 1 Peter 2:9 (Christianity) on chosen people.
3:111 (لَن يَضُرُّوكُمْ إِلَّا أَذًى...) They’ll only harm you with annoyance... Woh tumhe takleef ke siwa nuqsan na denge... 🛡️ Protection: Psalm 91:10 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:112 (ضُرِبَتْ عَلَيْهِمُ الذِّلَّةُ...) Humiliation struck them wherever they were... Un par zillat daali gayi jahan bhi paye gaye... ⚖️ Consequence: Deuteronomy 28:37 (Judaism) on disobedience.
3:113 (لَيْسُوا سَوَاءً...) Not all People of the Scripture are alike... Woh sab barabar nahi, Ahl-e-Kitab mein... 🤝 Righteous: Romans 11:5 (Christianity) on remnant.
3:114 (يُؤْمِنُونَ بِاللَّهِ...) They believe in Allah and the Last Day... Woh Allah aur aakhri din par iman rakhte hain... 🙏 Faith: Hebrews 11:6 (Christianity) on belief.
3:115 (وَمَا يَفْعَلُوا مِنْ خَيْرٍ...) Their good deeds won’t be denied... Jo nek kaam woh karenge, uska inkar na hoga... 🌟 Reward: Matthew 10:42 (Christianity) on acts.
3:116 (إِنَّ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا...) Disbelievers’ wealth won’t avail them... Kafiron ke maal Allah ke saamne kaam na aayenge... 💰 Impermanence: Luke 12:15 (Christianity) on wealth.
3:117 (مَثَلُ مَا يُنفِقُونَ...) What they spend in this life is like... Unki dunyavi zindagi mein kharch ki misal... 🌪️ Futility: Ecclesiastes 1:2 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:118 (يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا...) Don’t take outsiders as intimates... Apne siwa doosron ko raazdaar na banao... 🤝 Loyalty: 2 Corinthians 6:14 (Christianity) on alliances.
3:119 (هَا أَنتُمْ أُولَاءِ...) You love them, but they don’t love you... Tum unhe pyar karte ho, woh tumhe nahi... 💔 Unreciprocated: Matthew 5:44 (Christianity) on enemies.
3:120 (إِن تَمْسَسْكُمْ حَسَنَةٌ...) If good touches you, it distresses them... Agar tumhe achchai mile, woh pareshan hote hain... 😔 Envy: Psalm 37:1 (Judaism/Christianity) on fretting.
3:121 (وَإِذْ غَدَوْتَ مِنْ أَهْلِكَ...) When you left to station the believers for battle... Jab tum subah ghar se nikle jang ke liye... ⚔️ Uhud: Sets battle scene, akin to biblical wars.
3:122 (إِذْ هَمَّت طَّائِفَتَانِ...) Two parties nearly lost courage... Do jamaatein dil shikasta hone wali thi... 😟 Fear: Joshua 1:9 (Judaism/Christianity) on courage.
3:123 (وَلَقَدْ نَصَرَكُمُ اللَّهُ...) Allah gave you victory at Badr... Allah ne tumhe Badr mein madad di... 🏆 Victory: Exodus 14:14 (Judaism) on divine aid.
3:124 (إِذْ تَقُولُ لِلْمُؤْمِنِينَ...) You said, “Isn’t it enough that your Lord reinforces you...” Tumne kaha, “Kya kaafi nahi ke Rab madad kare...” 👼 Angels: 2 Kings 6:16 (Judaism/Christianity) on help.
3:125 (بَلَىٰ إِن تَصْبِرُوا...) Yes, if you’re patient and God-conscious... Haan, agar sabr aur taqwa rakho... 🌿 Patience: James 1:3-4 (Christianity) on perseverance.
3:126 (وَمَا جَعَلَهُ اللَّهُ...) Allah made it good tidings for you... Allah ne yeh khushkhabri ke taur par banaya... 🕊️ Assurance: Isaiah 41:10 (Judaism/Christianity) on comfort.
3:127 (لِيَقْطَعَ طَرَفًا...) To cut down some disbelievers... Kafiron ke ek hisse ko kaat de... ⚔️ Justice: Psalm 94:23 (Judaism/Christianity) on retribution.
3:128 (لَيْسَ لَكَ مِنَ الْأَمْرِ...) The decision isn’t yours, [O Muhammad]... Tumhare liye koi amr nahi... 🙏 Submission: Luke 22:42 (Christianity) on surrender.
3:129 (وَلِلَّهِ مَا فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ...) To Allah belongs all in heavens and earth... Allah ka hai jo aasmanon mein hai... 🌍 Sovereignty: Daniel 4:35 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:130 (يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا...) O believers, don’t consume usury... Aye iman walon, sood na khao... 💰 Prohibition: Leviticus 25:36 (Judaism) on interest.
3:131 (وَاتَّقُوا النَّارَ...) Fear the Fire prepared for disbelievers... Aag se daro jo kafiron ke liye hai... 🔥 Warning: Matthew 25:41 (Christianity) on hellfire.
3:132 (وَأَطِيعُوا اللَّهَ...) Obey Allah and the Messenger for mercy... Allah aur Rasool ki itaat karo... 🙏 Obedience: John 14:15 (Christianity) on commands.
3:133 (وَسَارِعُوا إِلَىٰ مَغْفِرَةٍ...) Hasten to your Lord’s forgiveness... Rab ki maghfirat ki taraf jaldi karo... 🏃‍♂️ Urgency: 2 Peter 3:9 (Christianity) on repentance.
3:134 (الَّذِينَ يُنفِقُونَ...) Those who spend in ease and hardship... Jo khushi aur takleef mein kharch karte hain... 💸 Generosity: 2 Corinthians 9:7 (Christianity) on giving.
3:135 (وَالَّذِينَ إِذَا فَعَلُوا...) Those who repent after wronging themselves... Jo badi ke baad tauba karte hain... 🙏 Repentance: 1 John 1:9 (Christianity) on confession.
3:136 (أُولَـٰئِكَ جَزَاؤُهُم...) Their reward is forgiveness... Unka badla maghfirat hai... 🌟 Forgiveness: Psalm 103:3 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:137 (قَدْ خَلَتْ مِن قَبْلِكُمْ...) Situations have passed before you... Tumse pehle tareeqe guzar chuke... 📜 History: Ecclesiastes 1:9 (Judaism/Christianity) on cycles.
3:138 (هَـٰذَا بَيَانٌ...) This is a statement, guidance, and instruction... Yeh wazeh bayan, hidayat aur naseehat hai... 📖 Guidance: 2 Timothy 3:16 (Christianity) on scripture.
3:139 (وَلَا تَهِنُوا...) Don’t weaken or grieve, you’ll be superior... Na kamzor ho na ghamgeen, tum ghaleb rahoge... 💪 Strength: Isaiah 40:31 (Judaism/Christianity) on renewal.
3:140 (إِن يَمْسَسْكُمْ قَرْحٌ...) If a wound touches you, they’ve felt the same... Agar tumhe zakhm lage, unhe bhi laga... ⚔️ Equality: Galatians 6:7 (Christianity) on reaping.
3:141 (وَلِيُمَحِّصَ اللَّهُ...) That Allah may purify believers... Taake Allah momineen ko paak kare... 🔥 Refinement: 1 Peter 1:7 (Christianity) on faith testing.
3:142 (أَمْ حَسِبْتُمْ...) Did you think you’d enter Paradise without proof... Kya socha Jannat mein jaoge bina aazmaish... 🧭 Testing: James 1:12 (Christianity) on trials.
3:143 (وَلَقَدْ كُنتُمْ...) You wished for death before facing it... Tum maut ki tamanna karte the... ⚔️ Reality: Matthew 26:41 (Christianity) on spirit vs. flesh.
3:144 (وَمَا مُحَمَّدٌ...) Muhammad is only a messenger, others passed before... Muhammad sirf Rasool hain, pehle bhi guzre... ☝️ Mortality: Distinct from Christian deification.
3:145 (وَمَا كَانَ لِنَفْسٍ...) No soul dies except by Allah’s permission... Koi jaan bina izn ke nahi marti... ⏳ Destiny: Ecclesiastes 3:2 (Judaism/Christianity) on times.
3:146 (وَكَأَيِّن مِّن نَّبِيٍّ...) Many prophets fought with scholars... Kitne Nabiyon ne ladai ki... ⚔️ Perseverance: Hebrews 11:32-34 (Christianity) on warriors.
3:147 (وَمَا كَانَ قَوْلَهُمْ...) They only said, “Our Lord, forgive us...” Unka qaul tha, “Rab hamein maaf kar...” 🙏 Forgiveness: Psalm 51:1 (Judaism/Christianity) on mercy.
3:148 (فَآتَاهُمُ اللَّهُ...) Allah gave them rewards here and hereafter... Allah ne duniya aur aakhirat ka ajr diya... 🌟 Reward: Matthew 5:12 (Christianity) on heaven.
3:149 (يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ...) If you obey disbelievers... Agar kafiron ki itaat karoge... ⚠️ Warning: 1 John 2:15 (Christianity) on influence.
3:150 (بَلِ اللَّهُ مَوْلَاكُمْ...) Allah is your protector, the best helper... Allah tumhara wali hai, behtareen madadgar... 🛡️ Protection: Psalm 121:2 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:151 (سَنُلْقِي فِي قُلُوبِ...) We’ll cast terror into disbelievers’ hearts... Hum kafiron ke dilon mein khauf daalenge... 😨 Fear: Exodus 23:27 (Judaism) on divine terror.
3:152 (وَلَقَدْ صَدَقَكُمُ...) Allah fulfilled His promise to you... Allah ne tumse wada sach kiya... ✅ Promise: 2 Corinthians 1:20 (Christianity) on faithfulness.
3:153 (إِذْ تُصْعِدُونَ...) When you fled without looking back... Jab tum chadh rahe the bina dekhe... 🏃‍♂️ Retreat: Reflects Uhud, akin to biblical defeats.
3:154 (ثُمَّ أَنزَلَ عَلَيْكُمْ...) Then He sent security after distress... Phir gham ke baad aman nazil kiya... 🕊️ Peace: John 14:27 (Christianity) on divine peace.
3:155 (إِنَّ الَّذِينَ تَوَلَّوْا...) Those who turned back when armies met... Jo pichhe hat gaye jab lashkar mile... ⚔️ Defection: Deuteronomy 20:8 (Judaism) on fear.
3:156 (يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ...) Don’t be like disbelievers... Un jaise na ho jo kafir hue... ⚠️ Caution: 1 Peter 4:4 (Christianity) on imitation.
3:157 (وَلَئِن قُتِلْتُمْ...) If killed or die in Allah’s cause... Agar Allah ke raaste mein qatl ho... 🌟 Martyrdom: Revelation 2:10 (Christianity) on martyrs.
3:158 (وَلَئِن مُّتُّمْ...) Whether you die or are killed, to Allah you return... Chahe maro ya qatl ho, Allah ki taraf jaoge... ⚖️ Judgment: Hebrews 9:27 (Christianity) on death.
3:159 (فَبِمَا رَحْمَةٍ...) By Allah’s mercy, you were lenient... Allah ki rehmat se tum narm hue... ❤️ Mercy: Ephesians 4:32 (Christianity) on kindness.
3:160 (إِن يَنصُرْكُمُ اللَّهُ...) If Allah aids you, none can overcome... Agar Allah madad kare, koi ghalib na hoga... 🛡️ Divine Aid: Romans 8:31 (Christianity) on support.
3:161 (وَمَا كَانَ لِنَبِيٍّ...) No prophet would act unfaithfully... Kisi Nabee ke liye khayanat nahi... ⚖️ Integrity: 1 Timothy 3:2 (Christianity) on conduct.
3:162 (أَفَمَنِ اتَّبَعَ...) Is one who seeks Allah’s pleasure like one who angers Him... Kya jo raza talash karta hai us jaisa hai... ✅ Righteousness: Matthew 6:33 (Christianity) on seeking.
3:163 (هُمْ دَرَجَاتٌ...) They are varying degrees with Allah... Woh Allah ke nazdeek darjaat mein hain... 🌟 Ranks: 1 Corinthians 15:41 (Christianity) on glories.
3:164 (لَقَدْ مَنَّ اللَّهُ...) Allah favored believers with a Messenger... Allah ne ehsaan kiya Rasool bhej kar... 📜 Messenger: John 3:16 (Christianity) on God’s gift.
3:165 (أَوَلَمَّا أَصَابَتْكُمْ...) When disaster struck you... Jab museebat aayi... ⚔️ Reflection: Job 1:21 (Judaism/Christianity) on adversity.
3:166 (وَمَا أَصَابَكُمْ...) What struck you when armies met... Jo us din aaya jab lashkar mile... ⚖️ Divine Will: Romans 8:28 (Christianity) on purpose.
3:167 (وَلِيَعْلَمَ الَّذِينَ...) To make hypocrites evident... Taake munafiqon ko zahir kare... 🕵️‍♂️ Exposure: Matthew 7:21-23 (Christianity) on falsity.
3:168 (الَّذِينَ قَالُوا...) Those who sat and said to their brothers... Jo baithe rahe aur bhaiyon se kehte the... ⚠️ Hypocrisy: Luke 6:46 (Christianity) on saying vs. doing.
3:169 (وَلَا تَحْسَبَنَّ...) Don’t think those killed in Allah’s cause are dead... Unhe murda na samjho jo qatl hue... 🌟 Martyrdom: Revelation 6:9-11 (Christianity) on souls.
3:170 (فَرِحِينَ بِمَا...) Rejoicing in Allah’s bounty... Khush hain us ehsaan se... 🎉 Joy: Philippians 4:4 (Christianity) on rejoicing.
3:171 (يَسْتَبْشِرُونَ...) Receiving good tidings of favor... Ne'mat aur fazl ki khushkhabri paate hain... 🕊️ Good News: Luke 2:10 (Christianity) on announcement.
3:172 (الَّذِينَ اسْتَجَابُوا...) Those who responded to Allah and the Messenger... Jo Allah aur Rasool ki dawat par laabeek kahte hain... 🙏 Obedience: 1 Samuel 15:22 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:173 (الَّذِينَ قَالَ لَهُمُ...) Those told, “People have gathered against you...” Jinse kaha gaya, “Log jama ho gaye...” 😨 Fearlessness: Psalm 27:1 (Judaism/Christianity) on fear.
3:174 (فَانقَلَبُوا بِنِعْمَةٍ...) They returned with favor and bounty... Woh ne'mat aur fazl ke saath wapas aaye... 🌟 Blessing: Numbers 6:24-26 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:175 (إِنَّمَا ذَٰلِكُمُ...) It’s only Satan frightening you... Woh sirf Shaitan hai jo daraata hai... 😈 Deception: 1 Peter 5:8 (Christianity) on devil’s schemes.
3:176 (وَلَا يَحْزُنكَ...) Don’t grieve over those hastening to disbelief... Unki wajah se gham na karo jo kufr mein jaldi karte hain... 😔 Grief: Matthew 5:4 (Christianity) on mourning.
3:177 (إِنَّ الَّذِينَ اشْتَرَوُا...) Those who trade faith for disbelief... Jo iman ke badle kufr khareedte hain... ❌ Exchange: Hebrews 12:16 (Christianity) on Esau.
3:178 (وَلَا يَحْسَبَنَّ...) Disbelievers shouldn’t think We extend their time... Kafir yeh na samjhein ke mohlat de rahe hain... ⏳ Delay: 2 Peter 3:9 (Christianity) on patience.
3:179 (مَّا كَانَ اللَّهُ...) Allah won’t leave believers as they are... Allah momineen ko is haalat par nahi chhodega... 🧭 Purification: 1 Corinthians 11:32 (Christianity) on discipline.
3:180 (وَلَا يَحْسَبَنَّ...) Don’t think those who withhold Allah’s gifts... Jo bakhili karte hain usmein... 💰 Greed: Luke 12:15 (Christianity) on covetousness.
3:181 (لَّقَدْ سَمِعَ اللَّهُ...) Allah heard those who said, “Allah is poor...” Allah ne suna jo kehte hain, “Allah faqeer hai...” 👂 Omniscience: Psalm 94:9 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:182 (ذَٰلِكَ بِمَا...) That’s due to what your hands put forth... Yeh uske wajah se hai jo haathon ne kiya... ⚖️ Accountability: Galatians 6:7 (Christianity) on reaping.
3:183 (الَّذِينَ قَالُوا...) Those who said, “Allah took our promise...” Jo kehte hain, “Allah ne ahd liya...” 📜 Covenant: Exodus 19:5 (Judaism) on pact.
3:184 (فَإِن كَذَّبُوكَ...) If they deny you, messengers were denied before... Agar tumhe jhutlate hain, pehle bhi jhutlaye gaye... 📜 Rejection: Matthew 5:12 (Christianity) on persecution.
3:185 (كُلُّ نَفْسٍ...) Every soul will taste death... Har nafs maut chakhegi... ⏳ Mortality: Hebrews 9:27 (Christianity) on death.
3:186 (لَتُبْلَوُنَّ...) You’ll be tested in wealth and selves... Tum maal aur jaan mein aazmaye jaoge... 🧭 Testing: James 1:2-3 (Christianity) on trials.
3:187 (وَإِذْ أَخَذَ اللَّهُ...) When Allah took a covenant from scripture holders... Jab Allah ne ahd liya Kitab walon se... 📜 Covenant: Deuteronomy 29:1 (Judaism) on Mosaic pact.
3:188 (لَا تَحْسَبَنَّ...) Don’t think those exulting in their deeds... Un logon ko na samjho jo khush hote hain... ⚠️ False Pride: Luke 18:9-14 (Christianity) on humility.
3:189 (وَلِلَّهِ مُلْكُ...) To Allah belongs dominion of heavens and earth... Allah ka hai aasmanon aur zameen ka mulk... 🌍 Sovereignty: Psalm 103:19 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:190 (إِنَّ فِي خَلْقِ...) In the creation of heavens and earth... Aasmanon aur zameen ki takhleeq mein... 🌌 Signs: Romans 1:20 (Christianity) on creation.
3:191 (الَّذِينَ يَذْكُرُونَ...) Who remember Allah standing, sitting, lying... Jo Allah ko yaad karte hain khade, baithe... 🙏 Remembrance: 1 Thessalonians 5:17 (Christianity) on prayer.
3:192 (رَبَّنَا مَا خَلَقْتَ...) “Our Lord, You didn’t create this aimlessly...” “Rab, Tu ne yeh bekar nahi banaya...” 🌟 Purpose: Ecclesiastes 3:1 (Judaism/Christianity) on purpose.
3:193 (رَبَّنَا إِنَّنَا...) “Our Lord, we heard a caller to faith...” “Rab, humne pukaarne wale ko suna...” 🕊️ Calling: Matthew 11:28 (Christianity) on invitation.
3:194 (رَبَّنَا فَاغْفِرْ...) “Our Lord, forgive our sins...” “Rab, hamaare gunah maaf kar...” 🙏 Forgiveness: Psalm 51:1-2 (Judaism/Christianity).
3:195 (فَاسْتَجَابَ لَهُمْ...) Their Lord responded, “I won’t waste any work...” Rab ne kaha, “Main amal zaya nahi karta...” 🌟 Justice: Matthew 16:27 (Christianity) on deeds.
3:196 (لَا يَغُرَّنَّكَ...) Don’t be deceived by disbelievers’ movement... Kafiron ki chalne phirne se dhoka na khao... ⚠️ Deception: 1 John 2:15-17 (Christianity) on allure.
3:197 (مَتَاعٌ قَلِيلٌ...) A small enjoyment, then Hell... Thoda sa faida, phir Jahannam... 🔥 Consequence: Luke 12:20 (Christianity) on wealth.
3:198 (لَـٰكِنِ الَّذِينَ...) But those who feared their Lord get gardens... Jo Rab se darte hain, unke liye Jannat... 🌿 Paradise: Revelation 22:1-2 (Christianity) on life.
3:199 (وَإِنَّ مِنْ أَهْلِ...) Some People of the Scripture believe in Allah... Ahl-e-Kitab mein kuch Allah par iman rakhte hain... 🤝 Faith: Acts 10:35 (Christianity) on righteous.
3:200 (يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ...) O believers, persevere, endure, remain stationed... Aye iman walon, sabr karo aur paband raho... 💪 Endurance: Hebrews 12:1 (Christianity) on race.

entry.content:
📖 Surah Al-Baqarah: Verse-by-Verse Analysis

Context: Surah Al-Baqarah, revealed in Medina, is the Quran’s longest chapter, addressing faith, law, prophetic narratives, and community building in a diverse post-Hijra society.
Purpose: Offers guidance on morality, legislation, and interfaith relations, using stories to impart timeless lessons.
Key Themes: Monotheism, guidance, legal frameworks, prophetic histories, and social cohesion.

Verse Arabic Text Transliteration English Translation Comparative Notes
1 الم Alif-Lam-Mim Alif-Lam-Mim Mystical letters akin to symbolic elements in Jewish Kabbalah (e.g., Hebrew alphabet), inviting contemplation of divine mystery.
2 ذَٰلِكَ الْكِتَابُ لَا رَيْبَ فِيهِ هُدًى لِلْمُتَّقِينَ Dhalika al-kitabu la rayba fihi hudan lil-muttaqeen This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah. Echoes Psalms 119:105 ("Your word is a lamp"), emphasizing scripture as divine guidance, a theme in Judaism and Hinduism (Vedas).
3 الَّذِينَ يُؤْمِنُونَ بِالْغَيْبِ وَيُقِيمُونَ الصَّلَاةَ وَمِمَّا رَزَقْنَاهُمْ يُنْفِقُونَ Alladhina yu'minuna bil-ghaybi wa yuqimuna as-salata wa mimma razaqnahum yunfiqun Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them. Faith in the unseen (Ghayb) parallels Hindu trust in Brahman. Prayer and charity align with Buddhist Five Precepts and Jewish tzedakah.
4 وَالَّذِينَ يُؤْمِنُونَ بِمَا أُنْزِلَ إِلَيْكَ وَمَا أُنْزِلَ مِنْ قَبْلِكَ وَبِالْآخِرَةِ هُمْ يُوقِنُونَ Walladhina yu'minuna bima unzila ilayka wa ma unzila min qablika wa bil-akhirati hum yuqinun And who believe in what has been revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you, and of the Hereafter they are certain [in faith]. Continuity with prior scriptures resembles Christian Old/New Testament link. Belief in Hereafter is a shared Abrahamic eschatological theme.
5 أُولَٰئِكَ عَلَىٰ هُدًى مِنْ رَبِّهِمْ ۖ وَأُولَٰئِكَ هُمُ الْمُفْلِحُونَ Ula'ika 'ala hudan min rabbihim wa ula'ika humu al-muflihun Those are upon [right] guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful. Guidance to success mirrors Buddhist Dharma leading to enlightenment. Success (Falah) as spiritual fulfillment is a universal religious goal.
6 إِنَّ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا سَوَاءٌ عَلَيْهِمْ أَأَنْذَرْتَهُمْ أَمْ لَمْ تُنْذِرْهُمْ لَا يُؤْمِنُونَ Inna alladhina kafaru sawa'un 'alayhim a'anzartahum am lam tunzirhum la yu'minun Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe. Similar to Matthew 13:13 (ears that hear not), reflecting spiritual resistance across traditions. Suggests a form of predestination akin to Calvinism.
7 خَتَمَ اللَّهُ عَلَىٰ قُلُوبِهِمْ وَعَلَىٰ سَمْعِهِمْ ۖ وَعَلَىٰ أَبْصَارِهِمْ غِشَاوَةٌ ۖ وَلَهُمْ عَذَابٌ عَظِيمٌ Khatama Allahu 'ala qulubihim wa 'ala sam'ihim wa 'ala absarihim ghishawatun walahum 'adhabun 'azim Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and upon their hearing, and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment. Sealing hearts parallels Pharaoh’s hardening in Exodus 9:12. Spiritual blindness akin to Hindu tamas (ignorance), with punishment as consequence.
8 وَمِنَ النَّاسِ مَنْ يَقُولُ آمَنَّا بِاللَّهِ وَبِالْيَوْمِ الْآخِرِ وَمَا هُمْ بِمُؤْمِنِينَ Wa mina an-nasi man yaqulu amanna billahi wa bil-yawmi al-akhiri wama hum bi-mu'minin And of the people are some who say, "We believe in Allah and the Last Day," but they are not believers. Hypocrisy critiqued in Matthew 23:27 (whitewashed tombs). False piety is a universal moral failing.
9 يُخَادِعُونَ اللَّهَ وَالَّذِينَ آمَنُوا وَمَا يَخْدَعُونَ إِلَّا أَنْفُسَهُمْ وَمَا يَشْعُرُونَ Yukhadi'una Allaha walladhina amanu wama yakhda'una illa anfusahum wama yash'urun They [think to] deceive Allah and those who believe, but they deceive only themselves and perceive [it] not. Self-deception mirrors Buddhist moha (delusion). Their failure to perceive harm echoes Proverbs 28:22.
10 فِي قُلُوبِهِمْ مَرَضٌ فَزَادَهُمُ اللَّهُ مَرَضًا ۖ وَلَهُمْ عَذَابٌ أَلِيمٌ بِمَا كَانُوا يَكْذِبُونَ Fi qulubihim maradun fazadahumu Allahu maradan walahum 'adhabun alimun bima kanu yakdhibun In their hearts is disease, so Allah has increased their disease; and for them is a painful punishment because they [habitually] used to lie. Diseased heart akin to sin’s corruption in Christian theology. Punishment for lying reflects universal ethical standards (e.g., Ten Commandments).
11 وَإِذَا قِيلَ لَهُمْ لَا تُفْسِدُوا فِي الْأَرْضِ قَالُوا إِنَّمَا نَحْنُ مُصْلِحُونَ Wa idha qila lahum la tufsidu fi al-ardi qalu innama nahnu muslihun And when it is said to them, "Do not cause corruption on the earth," they say, "We are but reformers." False righteousness parallels Confucian critiques of insincere virtue. Hypocrisy in claiming reform is a timeless issue.
12 أَلَا إِنَّهُمْ هُمُ الْمُفْسِدُونَ وَلَٰكِنْ لَا يَشْعُرُونَ Ala innahum humu al-mufsiduna walakin la yash'urun Unquestionably, it is they who are the corrupters, but they perceive [it] not. Ignorance of corruption echoes Socrates’ call to examine one’s life. Self-blindness is a philosophical and spiritual failing.
13 وَإِذَا قِيلَ لَهُمْ آمِنُوا كَمَا آمَنَ النَّاسُ قَالُوا أَنُؤْمِنُ كَمَا آمَنَ السُّفَهَاءُ ۖ أَلَا إِنَّهُمْ هُمُ السُّفَهَاءُ وَلَٰكِنْ لَا يَعْلَمُونَ Wa idha qila lahum aminu kama amana an-nasu qalu anu'minu kama amana as-sufaha'u ala innahum humu as-sufaha'u walakin la ya'lamun And when it is said to them, "Believe as the people have believed," they say, "Should we believe as the foolish have believed?" Unquestionably, it is they who are the foolish, but they know [it] not. Arrogance in rejecting faith mirrors Proverbs 12:15 (fools despise wisdom). Their ignorance of folly is a universal caution.
14 وَإِذَا لَقُوا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا قَالُوا آمَنَّا وَإِذَا خَلَوْا إِلَىٰ شَيَاطِينِهِمْ قَالُوا إِنَّا مَعَكُمْ إِنَّمَا نَحْنُ مُسْتَهْزِئُونَ Wa idha laqu alladhina amanu qalu amanna wa idha khalaw ila shayatinihim qalu inna ma'akum innama nahnu mustahzi'un And when they meet those who believe, they say, "We believe"; but when they are alone with their evil ones, they say, "Indeed, we are with you; we were only mockers." Duplicity condemned in Matthew 26:34 (Peter’s denial). Mockery reflects a lack of integrity across ethical traditions.
15 اللَّهُ يَسْتَهْزِئُ بِهِمْ وَيَمُدُّهُمْ فِي طُغْيَانِهِمْ يَعْمَهُونَ Allahu yastahzi'u bihim wa yamudduhum fi tughyanihim ya'mahun [But] Allah mocks them and prolongs them in their transgression [while] they wander blindly. Divine justice as mockery mirrors Galatians 6:7 ("God is not mocked"). Blind wandering akin to karmic consequence in Hinduism.
16 أُولَٰئِكَ الَّذِينَ اشْتَرَوُا الضَّلَالَةَ بِالْهُدَىٰ فَمَا رَبِحَتْ تِجَارَتُهُمْ وَمَا كَانُوا مُهْتَدِينَ Ula'ika alladhina ishtarawu ad-dalalata bil-huda fama rabihat tijaratuhum wama kanu muhtadin Those are the ones who have purchased error [in exchange] for guidance, so their transaction has brought no profit, nor were they guided. Trading guidance for error parallels Bhagavad Gita’s warnings against delusion. A failed spiritual transaction.
17 مَثَلُهُمْ كَمَثَلِ الَّذِي اسْتَوْقَدَ نَارًا فَلَمَّا أَضَاءَتْ مَا حَوْلَهُ ذَهَبَ اللَّهُ بِنُورِهِمْ وَتَرَكَهُمْ فِي ظُلُمَاتٍ لَا يُبْصِرُونَ Mathaluhum kamathali alladhi istawqada naran falamma ada'at ma hawlahu dhahaba Allahu binurihim watarakahum fi zulumatin la yubsirun Their example is that of one who kindled a fire, but when it illuminated what was around him, Allah took away their light and left them in darkness [so] they could not see. Loss of light symbolizes spiritual blindness, akin to Plato’s Allegory of the Cave (ignorance vs. enlightenment).
18 صُمٌّ بُكْمٌ عُمْيٌ فَهُمْ لَا يَرْجِعُونَ Summun bukmun 'umyun fahum la yarji'un Deaf, dumb, and blind - so they will not return [to the right path]. Sensory metaphors for spiritual failure appear in Isaiah 6:10. No return reflects entrenched disbelief.
19 أَوْ كَصَيِّبٍ مِنَ السَّمَاءِ فِيهِ ظُلُمَاتٌ وَرَعْدٌ وَبَرْقٌ يَجْعَلُونَ أَصَابِعَهُمْ فِي آذَانِهِمْ مِنَ الصَّوَاعِقِ حَذَرَ الْمَوْتِ ۚ وَاللَّهُ مُحِيطٌ بِالْكَافِرِينَ Aw kasayyibin mina as-sama'i fihi zulumatun wa ra'dun wa barqun yaj'aluna asabi'ahum fi adhanihim mina as-sawa'iqi hadhara al-mawti wallahu muhitun bil-kafirin Or [it is] like a rainstorm from the sky within which is darkness, thunder, and lightning. They put their fingers in their ears against the thunderclaps in dread of death. But Allah is encompassing of the disbelievers. Fearful reaction to signs parallels Buddhist samsaric confusion. God’s encompassing nature reflects divine omnipotence (cf. Psalm 139).
20 يَكَادُ الْبَرْقُ يَخْطَفُ أَبْصَارَهُمْ ۖ كُلَّمَا أَضَاءَ لَهُمْ مَشَوْا فِيهِ وَإِذَا أَظْلَمَ عَلَيْهِمْ قَامُوا ۚ وَلَوْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ لَذَهَبَ بِسَمْعِهِمْ وَأَبْصَارِهِمْ ۚ إِنَّ اللَّهَ عَلَىٰ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ Yakadu al-barqu yakhtafu absarahum kullama ada'a lahum mashaw fihi wa idha azlama 'alayhim qamu walaw shaa Allahu ladhahaba bisam'ihim wa absarihim inna Allaha 'ala kulli shay'in qadir The lightning almost snatches away their sight. Every time it lights [the way] for them, they walk therein; but when darkness comes over them, they stand [still]. And if Allah had willed, He could have taken away their hearing and their sight. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent. God’s power over senses echoes Job 42:5-6. Intermittent light/darkness symbolizes fleeting guidance they reject, a philosophical metaphor for truth-seeking.
21 يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ اعْبُدُوا رَبَّكُمُ الَّذِي خَلَقَكُمْ وَالَّذِينَ مِنْ قَبْلِكُمْ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَتَّقُونَ Ya ayyuha an-nasu u'budu rabbakumu alladhi khalaqakum walladhina min qablikum la'allakum tattaqun O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous. Universal call to worship aligns with Bhagavad Gita’s devotion to Krishna. Creation as basis for worship is a shared monotheistic theme.
22 الَّذِي جَعَلَ لَكُمُ الْأَرْضَ فِرَاشًا وَالسَّمَاءَ بِنَاءً وَأَنْزَلَ مِنَ السَّمَاءِ مَاءً فَأَخْرَجَ بِهِ مِنَ الثَّمَرَاتِ رِزْقًا لَكُمْ ۖ فَلَا تَجْعَلُوا لِلَّهِ أَنْدَادًا وَأَنْتُمْ تَعْلَمُونَ Alladhi ja'ala lakumu al-arda firashan was-sama'a bina'an wa anzala mina as-sama'i ma'an fa'akhraja bihi mina ath-thamarati rizqan lakum fala taj'alu lillahi andadan wa antum ta'lamun [He] who made for you the earth a bed [spread out] and the sky a ceiling and sent down from the sky, rain and brought forth thereby fruits as provision for you. So do not attribute to Allah equals while you know [that there is nothing similar to Him]. Nature as divine gift mirrors Vedic hymns. Prohibition of equals (Andad) reinforces monotheism against polytheism, a core Abrahamic principle.
23 وَإِنْ كُنْتُمْ فِي رَيْبٍ مِمَّا نَزَّلْنَا عَلَىٰ عَبْدِنَا فَأْتُوا بِسُورَةٍ مِنْ مِثْلِهِ وَادْعُوا شُهَدَاءَكُمْ مِنْ دُونِ اللَّهِ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ صَادِقِينَ Wa in kuntum fi raybin mimma nazzalna 'ala 'abdina fa'tu bisuratin min mithlihi wa ad'u shuhada'akum min duni Allahi in kuntum sadiqin And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our Servant [Muhammad], then produce a surah the like thereof and call upon your witnesses other than Allah, if you should be truthful. Unique Quranic challenge of inimitability has no direct parallel in other scriptures, emphasizing divine origin.
24 فَإِنْ لَمْ تَفْعَلُوا وَلَنْ تَفْعَلُوا فَاتَّقُوا النَّارَ الَّتِي وَقُودُهَا النَّاسُ وَالْحِجَارَةُ ۖ أُعِدَّتْ لِلْكَافِرِينَ Fa'in lam taf'alu walan taf'alu fattaqu an-nara allati waquduha an-nasu wal-hijaratu u'iddat lil-kafirin But if you do not - and you will never be able to - then fear the Fire, whose fuel is men and stones, prepared for the disbelievers. Hellfire imagery aligns with Christian (Revelation) and Zoroastrian eschatology, emphasizing punishment for disbelief.
25 وَبَشِّرِ الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا وَعَمِلُوا الصَّالِحَاتِ أَنَّ لَهُمْ جَنَّاتٍ تَجْرِي مِنْ تَحْتِهَا الْأَنْهَارُ ۖ كُلَّمَا رُزِقُوا مِنْهَا مِنْ ثَمَرَةٍ رِزْقًا ۙ قَالُوا هَٰذَا الَّذِي رُزِقْنَا مِنْ قَبْلُ ۖ وَأُتُوا بِهِ مُتَشَابِهًا ۖ وَلَهُمْ فِيهَا أَزْوَاجٌ مُطَهَّرَةٌ ۖ وَهُمْ فِيهَا خَالِدُونَ Wa bashshir alladhina amanu wa 'amilu as-salihati anna lahum jannatin tajri min tahtiha al-anharu... And they will have therein purified spouses, and they will abide therein eternally. Paradise with rivers aligns with Revelation 22:1-2. Eternal reward for faith/deeds is a shared eschatological promise across Abrahamic faiths.  
26 إِنَّ اللَّهَ لَا يَسْتَحْيِي أَنْ يَضْرِبَ مَثَلًا مَا بَعُوضَةً فَمَا فَوْقَهَا ۚ فَأَمَّا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا فَيَعْلَمُونَ أَنَّهُ الْحَقُّ مِنْ رَبِّهِمْ ۖ وَأَمَّا الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا فَيَقُولُونَ مَاذَا أَرَادَ اللَّهُ بِهَٰذَا مَثَلًا ۘ يُضِلُّ بِهِ كَثِيرًا وَيَهْدِي بِهِ كَثِيرًا ۚ وَمَا يُضِلُّ بِهِ إِلَّا الْفَاسِقِينَ Inna Allaha la yastahyi an yadriba mathalan ma ba'udatan fama fawqaha... yudillu bihi kathiran wa yahdi bihi kathiran wama yudillu bihi illa al-fasiqin Indeed, Allah is not timid to present an example - that of a mosquito or what is smaller than it... He misleads many thereby and guides many thereby. And He misleads not except the defiantly disobedient. Humble metaphors reflect Jesus’ parables (e.g., mustard seed, Matthew 13:31). Divine examples guide or mislead based on disposition, a concept of free will and justice.
27 الَّذِينَ يَنْقُضُونَ عَهْدَ اللَّهِ مِنْ بَعْدِ مِيثَاقِهِ وَيَقْطَعُونَ مَا أَمَرَ اللَّهُ بِهِ أَنْ يُوصَلَ وَيُفْسِدُونَ فِي الْأَرْضِ ۚ أُولَٰئِكَ هُمُ الْخَاسِرُونَ Alladhina yanquduna 'ahda Allahi min ba'di mithaqihi... ula'ika humu al-khasirun Who break the covenant of Allah after contracting it... It is those who are the losers. Covenant-breaking condemned in Deuteronomy 29:25. Loss reflects karmic consequence of disrupting divine order.
28 كَيْفَ تَكْفُرُونَ بِاللَّهِ وَكُنْتُمْ أَمْوَاتًا فَأَحْيَاكُمْ ۖ ثُمَّ يُمِيتُكُمْ ثُمَّ يُحْيِيكُمْ ثُمَّ إِلَيْهِ تُرْجَعُونَ Kayfa takfuruna billahi wakuntum amwatan fa'ahyakum thumma yumitukum thumma yuhyikum thumma ilayhi turja'un How can you disbelieve in Allah when you were lifeless and He brought you to life; then He will cause you to die, then He will bring you [back] to life, and then to Him you will be returned. Life/death cycle parallels Hindu samsara/moksha. Divine origin and return emphasize accountability, akin to Christian resurrection.
29 هُوَ الَّذِي خَلَقَ لَكُمْ مَا فِي الْأَرْضِ جَمِيعًا ثُمَّ اسْتَوَىٰ إِلَى السَّمَاءِ فَسَوَّاهُنَّ سَبْعَ سَمَاوَاتٍ ۚ وَهُوَ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ عَلِيمٌ Huwa alladhi khalaqa lakum ma fi al-ardi jami'an thumma istawa ila as-sama'i fasawwahunna sab'a samawatin wahuwa bikulli shay'in 'alim It is He who created for you all of that which is on the earth. Then He directed Himself to the heaven... and made them seven heavens, and He is Knowing of all things. Seven heavens resemble layered cosmologies in Zoroastrianism/Judaism. Creation for humanity underscores divine purpose and omniscience.
30 وَإِذْ قَالَ رَبُّكَ لِلْمَلَائِكَةِ إِنِّي جَاعِلٌ فِي الْأَرْضِ خَلِيفَةً ۖ قَالُوا أَتَجْعَلُ فِيهَا مَنْ يُفْسِدُ فِيهَا وَيَسْفِكُ الدِّمَاءَ وَنَحْنُ نُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِكَ وَنُقَدِّسُ لَكَ ۖ قَالَ إِنِّي أَعْلَمُ مَا لَا تَعْلَمُونَ Wa idh qala rabbuka lil-mala'ikati inni ja'ilun fi al-ardi khalifatan qalu ataj'alu fiha man yufsidu fiha wa yasfiku ad-dima'a wanahnu nusabbihu bihamdika wa nuqaddisu laka qala inni a'lamu ma la ta'lamun And [mention] when your Lord said to the angels, "Indeed, I will make upon the earth a successive authority." They said, "Will You place upon it one who causes corruption therein and sheds blood...?" Allah said, "Indeed, I know that which you do not know." Human stewardship (Khalifah) parallels Genesis 1:26-28. Angels’ concern vs. God’s knowledge reflects free will and divine purpose, unique in Islamic narrative.
31 وَعَلَّمَ آدَمَ الْأَسْمَاءَ كُلَّهَا ثُمَّ عَرَضَهُمْ عَلَى الْمَلَائِكَةِ فَقَالَ أَنْبِئُونِي بِأَسْمَاءِ هَٰؤُلَاءِ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ صَادِقِينَ Wa 'allama Adama al-asma'a kullaha thumma 'aradahum 'ala al-mala'ikati faqala anbi'uni bi'asma'i haulai in kuntum sadiqin And He taught Adam the names - all of them. Then He showed them to the angels and said, "Inform Me of the names of these, if you are truthful." Teaching names symbolizes human capacity for knowledge/language, akin to Greek idea of rational animals (Aristotle). Elevates humanity above angels.
32 قَالُوا سُبْحَانَكَ لَا عِلْمَ لَنَا إِلَّا مَا عَلَّمْتَنَا ۖ إِنَّكَ أَنْتَ الْعَلِيمُ الْحَكِيمُ Qalu subhanaka la 'ilma lana illa ma 'allamtana innaka anta al-'alimu al-hakim They said, "Exalted are You; we have no knowledge except what You have taught us. Indeed, it is You who is the Knowing, the Wise." Angels’ humility mirrors Isaiah 6:3 (praising God). Acknowledges divine omniscience/wisdom as source of all knowledge.
33 قَالَ يَا آدَمُ أَنْبِئْهُمْ بِأَسْمَائِهِمْ ۖ فَلَمَّا أَنْبَأَهُمْ بِأَسْمَائِهِمْ قَالَ أَلَمْ أَقُلْ لَكُمْ إِنِّي أَعْلَمُ غَيْبَ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ وَأَعْلَمُ مَا تُبْدُونَ وَمَا كُنْتُمْ تَكْتُمُونَ Qala ya Adamu anbi'hum bi'asma'ihim falamma anba'ahum bi'asma'ihim qala alam aqul lakum inni a'lamu ghayba as-samawati wal-ardi wa a'lamu ma tubduna wama kuntum taktumu He said, "O Adam, inform them of their names." And when he had informed them of their names, He said, "Did I not tell you that I know the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and the earth? And I know what you reveal and what you have concealed." God’s omniscience over unseen (Ghayb) aligns with Vedic hymns to Vishnu. Adam’s demonstration proves human potential under divine guidance.
34 وَإِذْ قُلْنَا لِلْمَلَائِكَةِ اسْجُدُوا لِآدَمَ فَسَجَدُوا إِلَّا إِبْلِيسَ أَبَىٰ وَاسْتَكْبَرَ وَكَانَ مِنَ الْكَافِرِينَ Wa idh qulna lil-mala'ikati usjudu li-Adama fasajadu illa Iblisa aba wastakbara wakana mina al-kafirin And [mention] when We said to the angels, "Prostrate before Adam"; so they prostrated, except for Iblis. He refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers. Iblis’ rebellion parallels Satan’s fall in Isaiah 14:12-15. Arrogance (Istakbara) as root of disbelief is a universal moral lesson.
35 وَقُلْنَا يَا آدَمُ اسْكُنْ أَنْتَ وَزَوْجُكَ الْجَنَّةَ وَكُلَا مِنْهَا رَغَدًا حَيْثُ شِئْتُمَا وَلَا تَقْرَبَا هَٰذِهِ الشَّجَرَةَ فَتَكُونَا مِنَ الظَّالِمِينَ Wa qulna ya Adamu uskuna anta wa zawjuka al-jannata wakula minha raghadan haythu shi'tuma wala taqraba hadhihi ash-shajarata fatakuna mina az-zalimin And We said, "O Adam, dwell, you and your wife, in Paradise and eat therefrom in [ease and] abundance from wherever you will. But do not approach this tree, lest you be among the wrongdoers." Forbidden tree story mirrors Genesis 2:16-17. Emphasis on obedience and consequence shapes early human narrative.
36 فَأَزَلَّهُمَا الشَّيْطَانُ عَنْهَا فَأَخْرَجَهُمَا مِمَّا كَانَا فِيهِ ۖ وَقُلْنَا اهْبِطُوا بَعْضُكُمْ لِبَعْضٍ عَدُوٌّ ۖ وَلَكُمْ فِي الْأَرْضِ مُسْتَقَرٌّ وَمَتَاعٌ إِلَىٰ حِينٍ Fa'azallahuma ash-shaytanu 'anha fa'akhrajahuma mimma kana fihi wa qulna ihbitu ba'dukum liba'din 'aduwwun walakum fi al-ardi mustaqarrun wamata'un ila hin But Satan caused them to slip out of it and removed them from that [condition] in which they had been. And We said, "Go down, [all of you], as enemies to one another, and you will have upon the earth a place of settlement and provision for a time." Expulsion aligns with Genesis 3:23-24. Satan as tempter and enmity introduced mirror Christian original sin narrative, though Islam emphasizes personal responsibility.
37 فَتَلَقَّىٰ آدَمُ مِنْ رَبِّهِ كَلِمَاتٍ فَتَابَ عَلَيْهِ ۚ إِنَّهُ هُوَ التَّوَّابُ الرَّحِيمُ Fatalaqa Adamu min rabbihi kalimatin fataba 'alayhi innahu huwa at-tawwabu ar-rahim Then Adam received from his Lord [some] words, and He accepted his repentance. Indeed, it is He who is the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful. Repentance and mercy parallel Psalm 51:1. Emphasis on God’s forgiveness (Tawwab, Rahim) distinguishes Islamic narrative from permanent fall.
38 قُلْنَا اهْبِطُوا مِنْهَا جَمِيعًا ۖ فَإِمَّا يَأْتِيَنَّكُمْ مِنِّي هُدًى فَمَنْ تَبِعَ هُدَايَ فَلَا خَوْفٌ عَلَيْهِمْ وَلَا هُمْ يَحْزَنُونَ Qulna ihbitu minha jami'an fa'imma ya'tiyannakum minni hudan faman tabi'a hudaya fala khawfun 'alayhim wala hum yahzanun We said, "Go down from it, all of you. And when guidance comes to you from Me, whoever follows My guidance - there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve." Guidance as path to peace mirrors Deuteronomy 30:19. Promise of no fear/grief for followers recurs as a key Quranic theme.
39 وَالَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا وَكَذَّبُوا بِآيَاتِنَا أُولَٰئِكَ أَصْحَابُ النَّارِ ۖ هُمْ فِيهَا خَالِدُونَ Walladhina kafaru wa kadhhabu bi'ayatina ula'ika ashabu an-nari hum fiha khalidun And those who disbelieve and deny Our signs - those will be companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally. Eternal punishment aligns with Christian/Zoroastrian eschatology. Denial of signs as disbelief is a Quranic emphasis.
40 يَا بَنِي إِسْرَائِيلَ اذْكُرُوا نِعْمَتِي الَّتِي أَنْعَمْتُ عَلَيْكُمْ وَأَوْفُوا بِعَهْدِي أُوفِ بِعَهْدِكُمْ وَإِيَّايَ فَارْهَبُونَ Ya bani Isra'ila udhkuru ni'mati allati an'amtu 'alaykum wa awfu bi'ahdi ufi bi'ahdikum wa iyyaya farhabun O Children of Israel, remember My favor that I have bestowed upon you and fulfill My covenant [upon you] that I will fulfill your covenant [from Me], and be afraid of [only] Me. Covenant with Israel mirrors Exodus 19:5. Emphasis on mutual obligation and exclusive reverence is a monotheistic hallmark.
41 وَآمِنُوا بِمَا أَنْزَلْتُ مُصَدِّقًا لِمَا مَعَكُمْ وَلَا تَكُونُوا أَوَّلَ كَافِرٍ بِهِ ۖ وَلَا تَشْتَرُوا بِآيَاتِي ثَمَنًا قَلِيلًا وَإِيَّايَ فَاتَّقُونَ Wa aminu bima anzaltu musaddiqan lima ma'akum wala takunu awwala kafirin bihi wala tashtaru bi'ayati thamanan qalilan wa iyyaya fattaqun And believe in what I have sent down confirming that which is [already] with you, and be not the first to disbelieve in it. And do not exchange My signs for a small price, and fear [only] Me. Confirmation of prior scriptures aligns with Christian prophetic continuity. Warning against selling faith echoes Matthew 21:12-13.
42 وَلَا تَلْبِسُوا الْحَقَّ بِالْبَاطِلِ وَتَكْتُمُوا الْحَقَّ وَأَنْتُمْ تَعْلَمُونَ Wala talbisu al-haqqa bil-batili wa taktum al-haqqa wa antum ta'lamun And do not mix the truth with falsehood or conceal the truth while you know [it]. Truthfulness reflects Buddhism’s Right Speech. Concealing truth knowingly is a grave ethical breach across traditions.
43 وَأَقِيمُوا الصَّلَاةَ وَآتُوا الزَّكَاةَ وَارْكَعُوا مَعَ الرَّاكِعِينَ Wa aqimu as-salata wa atu az-zakata warka'u ma'a ar-raki'in And establish prayer and give zakah and bow with those who bow [in worship and obedience]. Prayer and charity are pillars in Judaism/Christianity. Bowing signifies submission, a shared act of devotion.
44 أَتَأْمُرُونَ النَّاسَ بِالْبِرِّ وَتَنْسَوْنَ أَنْفُسَكُمْ وَأَنْتُمْ تَتْلُونَ الْكِتَابَ ۚ أَفَلَا تَعْقِلُونَ Ata'muruna an-nasa bil-birri wa tansawna anfusakum wa antum tatluna al-kitaba afala ta'qilun Do you order righteousness of the people and forget yourselves while you recite the Scripture? Then will you not reason? Hypocrisy in preaching mirrors Matthew 23:3. Call to reason (Ta'aqul) emphasizes self-reflection, a Socratic principle.
45 وَاسْتَعِينُوا بِالصَّبْرِ وَالصَّلَاةِ ۚ وَإِنَّهَا لَكَبِيرَةٌ إِلَّا عَلَى الْخَاشِعِينَ Wasta'inu bis-sabri was-salati wa innaha lakabiratan illa 'ala al-khashi'in And seek help through patience and prayer, and indeed, it is difficult except for the humbly submissive [to Allah]. Patience (Sabr) and prayer as virtues align with Stoicism/Buddhism. Ease for the humble (Khashi'in) reflects spiritual sincerity.
46 الَّذِينَ يَظُنُّونَ أَنَّهُمْ مُلَاقُو رَبِّهِمْ وَأَنَّهُمْ إِلَيْهِ رَاجِعُونَ Alladhina yazunnuna annahum mulaqu rabbihim wa annahum ilayhi raji'un Who are certain that they will meet their Lord and that to Him they will return. Accountability to God mirrors Hebrews 9:27. Certainty of return drives ethical behavior.
47 يَا بَنِي إِسْرَائِيلَ اذْكُرُوا نِعْمَتِي الَّتِي أَنْعَمْتُ عَلَيْكُمْ وَأَنِّي فَضَّلْتُكُمْ عَلَى الْعَالَمِينَ Ya bani Isra'ila udhkuru ni'mati allati an'amtu 'alaykum wa anni faddaltukum 'ala al-'alamin O Children of Israel, remember My favor which I have bestowed upon you and that I preferred you over the worlds. Chosen status echoes Exodus 19:5. Reminder of divine favor sets context for responsibility.
48 وَاتَّقُوا يَوْمًا لَا تَجْزِي نَفْسٌ عَنْ نَفْسٍ شَيْئًا وَلَا يُقْبَلُ مِنْهَا شَفَاعَةٌ وَلَا يُؤْخَذُ مِنْهَا عَدْلٌ وَلَا هُمْ يُنْصَرُونَ Wattaqu yawman la tajzi nafsun 'an nafsin shay'an wala yuqbalu minha shafa'atun wala yu'khadhu minha 'adlun wala hum yunsarun And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all, nor will intercession be accepted from it, nor will compensation be taken from it, nor will they be aided. Individual accountability parallels Hindu karma. No intercession without God’s will contrasts with some Christian views.
49 وَإِذْ نَجَّيْنَاكُمْ مِنْ آلِ فِرْعَوْنَ يَسُومُونَكُمْ سُوءَ الْعَذَابِ يُذَبِّحُونَ أَبْنَاءَكُمْ وَيَسْتَحْيُونَ نِسَاءَكُمْ ۚ وَفِي ذَٰلِكُمْ بَلَاءٌ مِنْ رَبِّكُمْ عَظِيمٌ Wa idh najjaynakum min ali Fir'awna yasumuunakum su'a al-'adhabi yudhabbihuna abna'akum wa yastahyuna nisa'akum wa fi dhalikum bala'un min rabbikum 'azim And [recall] when We saved you from the people of Pharaoh, who afflicted you with the worst torment... And in that was a great trial from your Lord. Liberation from Pharaoh mirrors Exodus 1:15-22. Trial (Bala') reflects divine testing, a shared theme.
50 وَإِذْ فَرَقْنَا بِكُمُ الْبَحْرَ فَأَنْجَيْنَاكُمْ وَأَغْرَقْنَا آلَ فِرْعَوْنَ وَأَنْتُمْ تَنْظُرُونَ Wa idh faraqna bikumu al-bahra fa'anjaynakum wa aghraqna ala Fir'awna wa antum tanzurun And [recall] when We parted the sea for you and saved you and drowned the people of Pharaoh while you were looking on. Parting of sea aligns with Exodus 14:21-22. Witnessed miracle underscores divine power and deliverance.
51 وَإِذْ وَاعَدْنَا مُوسَىٰ أَرْبَعِينَ لَيْلَةً ثُمَّ اتَّخَذْتُمُ الْعِجْلَ مِنْ بَعْدِهِ وَأَنْتُمْ ظَالِمُونَ Wa idh wa'adna Musa arba'ina laylatan thumma ittakhadhtumu al-'ijla min ba'dihi wa antum zalimun And [recall] when We made an appointment with Moses for forty nights. Then you took [for worship] the calf after him, while you were wrongdoers. Golden calf incident mirrors Exodus 32:1-4. Idolatry as wrongdoing (Zulm) is a recurring caution.
52 ثُمَّ عَفَوْنَا عَنْكُمْ مِنْ بَعْدِ ذَٰلِكَ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَشْكُرُونَ Thumma 'afawna 'ankum min ba'di dhalika la'allakum tashkurun Then We forgave you after that so perhaps you would be grateful. Divine forgiveness parallels Numbers 14:20. Gratitude (Shukr) as response to mercy is emphasized.
53 وَإِذْ آتَيْنَا مُوسَىٰ الْكِتَابَ وَالْفُرْقَانَ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَهْتَدُونَ Wa idh atayna Musa al-kitaba wal-furqana la'allakum tahtadun And [recall] when We gave Moses the Scripture and criterion that perhaps you would be guided. Torah as guidance mirrors Deuteronomy 31:9. Furqan (criterion) highlights discernment between right/wrong.
54 وَإِذْ قَالَ مُوسَىٰ لِقَوْمِهِ يَا قَوْمِ إِنَّكُمْ ظَلَمْتُمْ أَنْفُسَكُمْ بِاتِّخَاذِكُمُ الْعِجْلَ فَتُوبُوا إِلَىٰ بَارِئِكُمْ فَاقْتُلُوا أَنْفُسَكُمْ ذَٰلِكُمْ خَيْرٌ لَكُمْ عِنْدَ بَارِئِكُمْ فَتَابَ عَلَيْكُمْ ۚ إِنَّهُ هُوَ التَّوَّابُ الرَّحِيمُ Wa idh qala Musa liqawmihi ya qawmi innakum zalamtum anfusakum bittikhadhikumu al-'ijla fatubu ila bari'ikum faqtulu anfusakum dhalikum khayrun lakum 'inda bari'ikum fataba 'alaykum innahu huwa at-tawwabu ar-rahim And [recall] when Moses said to his people, "...So repent to your Creator and kill yourselves [i.e., the guilty among you]. That is best for [all of] you in the sight of your Creator." Then He accepted your repentance... Repentance through severe atonement echoes Leviticus 16 (scapegoat). Mercy (Rahim) after repentance is a key theme.
55 وَإِذْ قُلْتُمْ يَا مُوسَىٰ لَنْ نُؤْمِنَ لَكَ حَتَّىٰ نَرَى اللَّهَ جَهْرَةً فَأَخَذَتْكُمُ الصَّاعِقَةُ وَأَنْتُمْ تَنْظُرُونَ Wa idh qultum ya Musa lan nu'mina laka hatta nara Allaha jahratan fa'akhadhatkumu as-sa'iqatu wa antum tanzurun And [recall] when you said, "O Moses, we will never believe you until we see Allah outright"; so the thunderbolt took you while you were looking on. Demand for visible proof parallels Exodus 19:16-17. Thunderbolt reflects divine reprimand for doubting faith.
56 ثُمَّ بَعَثْنَاكُمْ مِنْ بَعْدِ مَوْتِكُمْ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَشْكُرُونَ Thumma ba'athnakum min ba'di mawtikum la'allakum tashkurun Then We revived you after your death that perhaps you would be grateful. Revival as a sign mirrors Ezekiel 37:1-14. Gratitude (Shukr) reinforces awareness of divine favor.
57 وَظَلَّلْنَا عَلَيْكُمُ الْغَمَامَ وَأَنْزَلْنَا عَلَيْكُمُ الْمَنَّ وَالسَّلْوَىٰ ۖ كُلُوا مِنْ طَيِّبَاتِ مَا رَزَقْنَاكُمْ ۖ وَمَا ظَلَمُونَا وَلَٰكِنْ كَانُوا أَنْفُسَهُمْ يَظْلِمُونَ Wa zallalna 'alaykumu al-ghamama wa anzalna 'alaykumu al-manna was-salwa kulu min tayyibati ma razaqnakum wama zalamuna walakin kanu anfusahum yazlimun And We shaded you with clouds and sent down to you manna and quails... And they wronged Us not, but they were [only] wronging themselves. Manna/quails parallel Exodus 16:4-15. Self-wronging reflects personal accountability, not divine injustice.
58 وَإِذْ قُلْنَا ادْخُلُوا هَٰذِهِ الْقَرْيَةَ فَكُلُوا مِنْهَا حَيْثُ شِئْتُمْ رَغَدًا وَادْخُلُوا الْبَابَ سُجَّدًا وَقُولُوا حِطَّةٌ نَغْفِرْ لَكُمْ خَطَايَاكُمْ ۚ وَسَنَزِيدُ الْمُحْسِنِينَ Wa idh qulna udkhulu hadhihi al-qaryata fakulu minha haythu shi'tum raghadan wa udkhulu al-baba sujjadan wa qulu hittatun naghfir lakum khatayakum wasanazidu al-muhsinin And [recall] when We said, "Enter this city and eat from it... and enter the gate bowing humbly and say, 'Relieve us of our burdens.' We will [then] forgive your sins for you..." Humble entry mirrors Jewish repentance rituals. Forgiveness and reward for good-doers (Muhsinin) are recurring themes.
59 فَبَدَّلَ الَّذِينَ ظَلَمُوا قَوْلًا غَيْرَ الَّذِي قِيلَ لَهُمْ فَأَنْزَلْنَا عَلَى الَّذِينَ ظَلَمُوا رِجْزًا مِنَ السَّمَاءِ بِمَا كَانُوا يَفْسُقُونَ Fabaddala alladhina zalamu qawlan ghayra alladhi qila lahum fa'anzalna 'ala alladhina zalamu rijzan mina as-sama'i bima kanu yafsuqun But those who wronged changed [those words] to a statement other than that which had been said to them, so We sent down upon those who wronged a punishment from the sky because they were defiantly disobeying. Punishment for disobedience echoes Numbers 14:28-30. Defiance (Fisq) leads to divine retribution.
60 وَإِذِ اسْتَسْقَىٰ مُوسَىٰ لِقَوْمِهِ فَقُلْنَا اضْرِبْ بِعَصَاكَ الْحَجَرَ ۖ فَانْفَجَرَتْ مِنْهُ اثْنَتَا عَشْرَةَ عَيْنًا ۖ قَدْ عَلِمَ كُلُّ أُنَاسٍ مَشْرَبَهُمْ ۖ كُلُوا وَاشْرَبُوا مِنْ رِزْقِ اللَّهِ وَلَا تَعْثَوْا فِي الْأَرْضِ مُفْسِدِينَ Wa idhi istasqa Musa liqawmihi faqulna idrib bi'asaka al-hajara fanfajarat minhu ithnata 'ashrata 'aynan qad 'alima kullu unasin mashrabahum kulu washrabu min rizqi Allahi wala ta'thaw fi al-ardi mufsidin And [recall] when Moses prayed for water for his people, so We said, "Strike with your staff the stone." And there gushed forth from it twelve springs... "Eat and drink from the provision of Allah, and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption." Water from rock parallels Exodus 17:6. Twelve springs for tribes reflect divine order. Warning against corruption reinforces stewardship.
61 وَإِذْ قُلْتُمْ يَا مُوسَىٰ لَنْ نَصْبِرَ عَلَىٰ طَعَامٍ وَاحِدٍ فَادْعُ لَنَا رَبَّكَ يُخْرِجْ لَنَا مِمَّا تُنْبِتُ الْأَرْضُ مِنْ بَقْلِهَا وَقِثَّائِهَا وَفُومِهَا وَعَدَسِهَا وَبَصَلِهَا ۖ قَالَ أَتَسْتَبْدِلُونَ الَّذِي هُوَ أَدْنَىٰ بِالَّذِي هُوَ خَيْرٌ ۚ اهْبِطُوا مِصْرًا فَإِنَّ لَكُمْ مَا سَأَلْتُمْ ۗ وَضُرِبَتْ عَلَيْهِمُ الذِّلَّةُ وَالْمَسْكَنَةُ وَبَاءُوا بِغَضَبٍ مِنَ اللَّهِ ۗ ذَٰلِكَ بِأَنَّهُمْ كَانُوا يَكْفُرُونَ بِآيَاتِ اللَّهِ وَيَقْتُلُونَ النَّبِيِّينَ بِغَيْرِ الْحَقِّ ۗ ذَٰلِكَ بِمَا عَصَوْا وَكَانُوا يَعْتَدُونَ Wa idh qultum ya Musa lan nasbira 'ala ta'amin wahidin fad'u lana rabbaka yukhrij lana mimma tunbitu al-ardu min baqliha wa qiththa'iha wa fumiha wa 'adasiha wa basaliha qala atastabdiluna alladhi huwa adna billadhi huwa khayrun ihbitu misran fa'inna lakum ma sa'altum waduribat 'alayhimu adh-dhillatu wal-maskanatu wa ba'u bighadabin mina Allahi dhalika bi'annahum kanu yakfuruna bi'ayati Allahi wa yaqtuluna an-nabiyyina bighayri al-haqqi dhalika bima 'asaw wakana ya'tadun And [recall] when you said, "O Moses, we can never endure one [kind of] food. So call upon your Lord to bring forth for us from the earth its green herbs..." [Moses] said, "Would you exchange what is better for what is less?..." And they were covered with humiliation and poverty and returned with anger from Allah... Ingratitude and punishment echo Numbers 11:4-6. Trading divine gifts for lesser desires reflects human folly, leading to divine wrath.
62 إِنَّ الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا وَالَّذِينَ هَادُوا وَالنَّصَارَىٰ وَالصَّابِئِينَ مَنْ آمَنَ بِاللَّهِ وَالْيَوْمِ الْآخِرِ وَعَمِلَ صَالِحًا فَلَهُمْ أَجْرُهُمْ عِنْدَ رَبِّهِمْ وَلَا خَوْفٌ عَلَيْهِمْ وَلَا هُمْ يَحْزَنُونَ Inna alladhina amanu walladhina hadu wan-nasara was-sabi'ina man amana billahi wal-yawmi al-akhiri wa 'amila salihan falahum ajruhum 'inda rabbihim wala khawfun 'alayhim wala hum yahzanun Indeed, those who believed and those who were Jews or Christians or Sabeans [before Prophet Muhammad] - those [among them] who believed in Allah and the Last Day and did righteousness - will have their reward with their Lord... Inclusive salvation rare, akin to Judaism’s “righteous gentiles.” Faith and deeds as criteria transcend religious labels.
63 وَإِذْ أَخَذْنَا مِيثَاقَكُمْ وَرَفَعْنَا فَوْقَكُمُ الطُّورَ ۖ قُولُوا مَا آتَيْنَاكُمْ بِقُوَّةٍ وَاذْكُرُوا مَا فِيهِ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَتَّقُونَ Wa idh akhadhna mithaqakum wa rafa'na fawqakumu at-tura qulu ma ataynakum biquwwatin wadhkuru ma fihi la'allakum tattaqun And [recall] when We took your covenant... and We raised over you the mount, [saying], "Take what We have given you with determination..." Mount Sinai covenant mirrors Exodus 19:17-18. Emphasis on taking law seriously fosters piety (Taqwa).
64 ثُمَّ تَوَلَّيْتُمْ مِنْ بَعْدِ ذَٰلِكَ ۖ فَلَوْلَا فَضْلُ اللَّهِ عَلَيْكُمْ وَرَحْمَتُهُ لَكُنْتُمْ مِنَ الْخَاسِرِينَ Thumma tawallaytum min ba'di dhalika falawla fadlu Allahi 'alaykum wa rahmatuhu lakuntum mina al-khasirin Then you turned away after that. And if not for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy, you would have been among the losers. Mercy despite disobedience parallels Hosea 11:8-9. Loss avoided through divine grace.
65 وَلَقَدْ عَلِمْتُمُ الَّذِينَ اعْتَدَوْا مِنْكُمْ فِي السَّبْتِ فَقُلْنَا لَهُمْ كُونُوا قِرَدَةً خَاسِئِينَ Walaqad 'alimtumu alladhina i'tadaw minkum fi as-sabti faqulna lahum kunu qiradatan khasi'in And you had already known about those who transgressed among you concerning the sabbath, and We said to them, "Be apes, despised." Sabbath violation punishment unique, but echoes Torah’s strict laws (Numbers 15:32-36). Transformation as lesson.
66 فَجَعَلْنَاهَا نَكَالًا لِمَا بَيْنَ يَدَيْهَا وَمَا خَلْفَهَا وَمَوْعِظَةً لِلْمُتَّقِينَ Faja'alnaha nakalan lima bayna yadayha wama khalfaha wa maw'izatan lil-muttaqin And We made it a deterrent punishment... and a lesson for those who fear Allah. Exemplary punishment mirrors Deuteronomy 13:11. Lesson (Maw'izah) for the pious (Muttaqin).
67 وَإِذْ قَالَ مُوسَىٰ لِقَوْمِهِ إِنَّ اللَّهَ يَأْمُرُكُمْ أَنْ تَذْبَحُوا بَقَرَةً ۖ قَالُوا أَتَتَّخِذُنَا هُزُوًا ۖ قَالَ أَعُوذُ بِاللَّهِ أَنْ أَكُونَ مِنَ الْجَاهِلِينَ Wa idh qala Musa liqawmihi inna Allaha ya'murukum an tadhbahu baqaratan qalu atattakhidhuna huzuwan qala a'udhu billahi an akuna mina al-jahilin And [recall] when Moses said to his people, "Indeed, Allah commands you to slaughter a cow." They said, "Do you take us in ridicule?"... Cow story unique, reflects obedience tests in Torah (e.g., Abraham’s sacrifice). Initial disbelief shows reluctance.
68 قَالُوا ادْعُ لَنَا رَبَّكَ يُبَيِّنْ لَنَا مَا هِيَ ۚ قَالَ إِنَّهُ يَقُولُ إِنَّهَا بَقَرَةٌ لَا فَارِضٌ وَلَا بِكْرٌ عَوَانٌ بَيْنَ ذَٰلِكَ ۖ فَافْعَلُوا مَا تُؤْمَرُونَ Qalu ud'u lana rabbaka yubayyin lana ma hiya qala innahu yaqulu innaha baqaratun la faridun wala bikrun 'awanun bayna dhalika faf'alu ma tu'marun They said, "Call upon your Lord to make clear to us what it is." [Moses] said, "[Allah] says, 'It is a cow neither old nor virgin, but median between that,' so do what you are commanded." Excessive questioning contrasts with Abraham’s obedience (Genesis 22). Specificity tests sincerity.
69 قَالُوا ادْعُ لَنَا رَبَّكَ يُبَيِّنْ لَنَا مَا لَوْنُهَا ۚ قَالَ إِنَّهُ يَقُولُ إِنَّهَا بَقَرَةٌ صَفْرَاءُ فَاقِعٌ لَوْنُهَا تَسُرُّ النَّاظِرِينَ Qalu ud'u lana rabbaka yubayyin lana ma lawnuha qala innahu yaqulu innaha baqaratun safra'u faqi'un lawnuha tasurru an-nazirin They said, "Call upon your Lord to show us what is her color." He said, "[Allah] says, 'It is a yellow cow, bright in color - pleasing to the observers.'" Continued specificity delays obedience, reflecting reluctance. Bright color adds vividness to the command.
70 قَالُوا ادْعُ لَنَا رَبَّكَ يُبَيِّنْ لَنَا مَا هِيَ إِنَّ الْبَقَرَ تَشَابَهَ عَلَيْنَا وَإِنَّا إِنْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ لَمُهْتَدُونَ Qalu ud'u lana rabbaka yubayyin lana ma hiya inna al-baqara tashabaha 'alayna wa inna in sha'a Allahu lamuhtadun They said, "Call upon your Lord to make clear to us what it is. Indeed, [all] cows look alike to us. And indeed we, if Allah wills, will be guided." Claiming confusion despite details shows hesitation. "In sha Allah" acknowledges divine guidance needed.
71 قَالَ إِنَّهُ يَقُولُ إِنَّهَا بَقَرَةٌ لَا ذَلُولٌ تُثِيرُ الْأَرْضَ وَلَا تَسْقِي الْحَرْثَ مُسَلَّمَةٌ لَا شِيَةَ فِيهَا ۚ قَالُوا الْآنَ جِئْتَ بِالْحَقِّ ۚ فَذَبَحُوهَا وَمَا كَادُوا يَفْعَلُونَ Qala innahu yaqulu innaha baqaratun la dhalulun tuthiru al-arda wala tasqi al-hartha musallamatun la shiyata fiha qalu al-'ana ji'ta bil-haqqi fadhaba huha wama kadu yaf'alun He said, "[Allah] says, 'It is a cow neither trained to plow the earth nor to water the field...'" They said, "Now you have come with the truth." So they slaughtered her, but they could hardly do it. Final details overcome reluctance. Hesitant compliance ("hardly do it") fulfills command, revealing divine wisdom in specificity.
72 وَإِذْ قَتَلْتُمْ نَفْسًا فَادَّارَأْتُمْ فِيهَا ۖ وَاللَّهُ مُخْرِجٌ مَا كُنْتُمْ تَكْتُمُونَ Wa idh qataltum nafsan fa-iddara'tum fiha wallahu mukhrijun ma kuntum taktumun And [recall] when you slew a man and disputed over it, but Allah was to bring out that which you were concealing. Murder mystery underlies cow command. Divine justice ensures truth emerges, a universal principle.
73 فَقُلْنَا اضْرِبُوهُ بِبَعْضِهَا ۚ كَذَٰلِكَ يُحْيِي اللَّهُ الْمَوْتَىٰ وَيُرِيكُمْ آيَاتِهِ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَعْقِلُونَ Faqulna idribuhu biba'diha kadhalika yuhyi Allahu al-mawta wayurikum ayatihi la'allakum ta'qilun So, We said, "Strike the slain man with part of it." Thus does Allah bring the dead to life, and He shows you His signs that you might reason. Miracle of temporary resurrection (cf. Elisha, 2 Kings 4) reveals killer. Demonstrates God’s power over death, encouraging reason (Ta'aqul).
74 ثُمَّ قَسَتْ قُلُوبِكُمْ مِنْ بَعْدِ ذَٰلِكَ فَهِيَ كَالْحِجَارَةِ أَوْ أَشَدُّ قَسْوَةً ۚ وَإِنَّ مِنَ الْحِجَارَةِ لَمَا يَتَفَجَّرُ مِنْهُ الْأَنْهَارُ ۚ وَإِنَّ مِنْهَا لَمَا يَشَّقَّقُ فَيَخْرُجُ مِنْهُ الْمَاءُ ۚ وَإِنَّ مِنْهَا لَمَا يَهْبِطُ مِنْ خَشْيَةِ اللَّهِ ۗ وَمَا اللَّهُ بِغَافِلٍ عَمَّا تَعْمَلُونَ Thumma qasat qulubukum min ba'di dhalika fahiya kal-hijarati aw ashaddu qaswatan... wama Allahu bighafilin 'amma ta'malun Then your hearts became hardened after that, being like stones or even harder... And Allah is not unaware of what you do. Hard hearts despite miracles echo Pharaoh’s resistance (Exodus). Stones yielding water/fearing God contrast human stubbornness, urging awareness.
75 أَفَتَطْمَعُونَ أَنْ يُؤْمِنُوا لَكُمْ وَقَدْ كَانَ فَرِيقٌ مِنْهُمْ يَسْمَعُونَ كَلَامَ اللَّهِ ثُمَّ يُحَرِّفُونَهُ مِنْ بَعْدِ مَا عَقَلُوهُ وَهُمْ يَعْلَمُونَ Afatatma'una an yu'minu lakum waqad kana fariqun minhum yasma'una kalama Allahi thumma yuharrifunahu min ba'di ma 'aqaluhu wahum ya'lamun Do you covet [the hope] that they would believe for you while a party of them used to hear the words of Allah and then distort them...? Distorting scripture knowingly reflects historical critique. Hope in their belief is questioned due to past actions.
76 وَإِذَا لَقُوا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا قَالُوا آمَنَّا وَإِذَا خَلَا بَعْضُهُمْ إِلَىٰ بَعْضٍ قَالُوا أَتُحَدِّثُونَهُمْ بِمَا فَتَحَ اللَّهُ عَلَيْكُمْ لِيُحَاجُّوكُمْ بِهِ عِنْدَ رَبِّكُمْ ۚ أَفَلَا تَعْقِلُونَ Wa idha laqu alladhina amanu qalu amanna wa idha khala ba'duhum ila ba'din qalu atuhaddithunahum bima fataha Allahu 'alaykum liyuhajjukum bihi 'inda rabbikum afala ta'qilun And when they meet those who believe, they say, "We have believed"; but when they are alone with one another, they say, "Do you talk to them about what Allah has revealed to you...?" Hypocrisy and fear of scripture validating Islam reflect internal conflict. Call to reason (Ta'aqul) challenges their logic.
77 أَوَلَا يَعْلَمُونَ أَنَّ اللَّهَ يَعْلَمُ مَا يُسِرُّونَ وَمَا يُعْلِنُونَ Awala ya'lamuna anna Allaha ya'lamu ma yusirruna wama yu'linun But do they not know that Allah knows what they conceal and what they declare? Divine omniscience over secret/public acts is a universal theological principle (e.g., Psalm 44:21).
78 وَمِنْهُمْ أُمِّيُّونَ لَا يَعْلَمُونَ الْكِتَابَ إِلَّا أَمَانِيَّ وَإِنْ هُمْ إِلَّا يَظُنُّونَ Wa minhum ummiyyuna la ya'lamuna al-kitaba illa amaniyya wa in hum illa yazunnun And among them are unlettered ones who do not know the Scripture except in wishful thinking, but they are only assuming. Ignorant followers relying on hearsay contrast with learned manipulators (v.75). Critique of blind faith vs. knowledge.
79 فَوَيْلٌ لِلَّذِينَ يَكْتُبُونَ الْكِتَابَ بِأَيْدِيهِمْ ثُمَّ يَقُولُونَ هَٰذَا مِنْ عِنْدِ اللَّهِ لِيَشْتَرُوا بِهِ ثَمَنًا قَلِيلًا ۖ فَوَيْلٌ لَهُمْ مِمَّا كَتَبَتْ أَيْدِيهِمْ وَوَيْلٌ لَهُمْ مِمَّا يَكْسِبُونَ Fawaylun lilladhina yaktubuna al-kitaba bi'aydihim thumma yaquluna hadha min 'indi Allahi liyashtaru bihi thamanan qalilan fawaylun lahum mimma katabat aydihim wawaylun lahum mimma yaksibun So woe to those who write the "scripture" with their own hands, then say, "This is from Allah," in order to exchange it for a small price... Forging scripture for gain echoes Jeremiah 23:16. Triple "woe" underscores severity of corrupting divine truth.
80 وَقَالُوا لَنْ تَمَسَّنَا النَّارُ إِلَّا أَيَّامًا مَعْدُودَةً ۚ قُلْ أَتَّخَذْتُمْ عِنْدَ اللَّهِ عَهْدًا فَلَنْ يُخْلِفَ اللَّهُ عَهْدَهُ ۖ أَمْ تَقُولُونَ عَلَى اللَّهِ مَا لَا تَعْلَمُونَ Wa qalu lan tamassana an-naru illa ayyaman ma'dudatan qul attakhadhtum 'inda Allahi 'ahdan falan yukhlifa Allahu 'ahdahu am taquluna 'ala Allahi ma la ta'lamun And they say, "Never will the Fire touch us, except for a few days." Say, "Have you taken a covenant from Allah?..." Rejects claims of immunity based on lineage, challenging false assurances with demand for proof. Accountability transcends identity.
81 بَلَىٰ مَنْ كَسَبَ سَيِّئَةً وَأَحَاطَتْ بِهِ خَطِيئَتُهُ فَأُولَٰئِكَ أَصْحَابُ النَّارِ ۖ هُمْ فِيهَا خَالِدُونَ Bala man kasaba sayyi'atan wa ahatat bihi khati'atuhu fa'ula'ika ashabu an-nari hum fiha khalidun Yes, whoever earns evil and his sin has encompassed him - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally. Overwhelming sin leads to eternal punishment, emphasizing personal responsibility over group privilege.
82 وَالَّذِينَ آمَنُوا وَعَمِلُوا الصَّالِحَاتِ أُولَٰئِكَ أَصْحَابُ الْجَنَّةِ ۖ هُمْ فِيهَا خَالِدُونَ Walladhina amanu wa 'amilu as-salihati ula'ika ashabu al-jannati hum fiha khalidun But they who believe and do righteous deeds - those are the companions of Paradise; they will abide therein eternally. Faith and good deeds as path to eternal reward is a universal religious principle (e.g., Matthew 25:46).
